dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Total darkness. We hear an old man's voice, distinct and distress. It is OLD SALIERI. He uses a mixture of English and occasionally Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart! Mozart! Mozart. Forgive me!   Forgive your assassin! Mozart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faint light illuminates the screen. Flickeringly, we se an eighteenth century balustrade and a flight of stone st We are looking down into the wall of the staircase from t point of view of the landing. Up the stair is coming a  branched candlestick held by Salieri's VALET. By his side Salieri's COOK, bearing a large dish of sugared cakes and biscuits. Both men are desperately worried: the Valet is  thin and middle-aged; the Cook, plump and Italian. It is  very cold. They wear shawls over their night-dresses and  clogs on their feet. They wheeze as they climb. The candl throw their shadows up onto the peeling walls of the hous which is evidently an old one and in bad decay. A cat scu swiftly between their bare legs, as they reach the salon  door. The Valet tries the handle. It is locked. Behind it the v goes on, rising in volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show some mercy! I beg you. I beg  you! Show mercy to a guilty man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Valet knocks gently on the door. The voice stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door, Signore! Please! Be  good now! We've brought you something  special. Something you're going to  love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signore Salieri! Open the door. Come  now. Be good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice of Old Salieri continues again, further off now and louder. We hear a noise as if a window is being opene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart! Mozart! I confess it! Listen!  I confess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two servants look at each other in alarm. Then the Va hands the candlestick to the Cook and takes a sugared cak from the dish, scrambling as quickly as he can back down stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is filled with people: ten cabs with drivers,  five children, fifteen adults, two doormen, fifteen danci couples and a sled and three dogs. It is a windy night. S is falling and whirling about. People are passing on foot holding their cloaks tightly around them. Some of them ar revelers in fancy dress: they wear masks on their faces o hanging around their necks, as if returning from parties. Now they are glancing up at the facade of the old house. The window above the street is open and Old Salieri stand there calling to the sky: a sharp-featured, white-haired  Italian over seventy years old, wearing a stained dressin gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart! Mozart! I cannot bear it any  longer! I confess! I confess what I  did! I'm guilty! I killed you! Sir   I confess! I killed you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of the house bursts open. The Valet hobbles out, holding the sugared cake. The wind catches at his shawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart, perdonami! Forgive your  assassin! PietВ€! PietВ€! Forgive your  assassin! Forgive me! Forgive!  Forgive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up to the  window) That's all right, Signore! He heard  you! He forgave you! He wants you to  go inside now and shut the window!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Salieri stares down at him. Some of the passersby hav now stopped and are watching this spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Signore! Look what I have  for you! I can't give it to you from  down here, can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Salieri looks at him in contempt. Then he turns away  back into the room, shutting the window with a bang. Thro the glass, the old man stares down at the group of onlook in the street. They stare back at him in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one, sir. He'll be all right.  Poor man. He's a little unhappy, you  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a sign indicating 'crazy,' and goes back inside house. The onlookers keep staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cook is standing holding the candlestick in one hand, the dish of cakes in the other. The Valet arrives, pantin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cook, scared, shakes his head: no. The Valet again kn on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am, Signore. Now open the  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eats the sugared cake in his hand, elaborately and noi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm - this is good! This is the  most delicious thing I ever ate,  believe me! Signore, you don't know  what you're missing! Mmmm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a thump from inside the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's enough, Signore! Open!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a terrible, throaty groaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't open this door, we're  going to eat everything. There'll be  nothing left for you. And I'm not  going to bring you anything more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down. From under the door we see a trickle of bl flowing. In horror, the two men stare at it. The dish of  cakes falls from the Cook's hand and shatters. He sets the candlestick down on the floor. Both servants at the door frantically - once, twice, three times - and frail lock gives. The door flies open. Immediately, the stormy, frenzied opening of Mozart's Sym No. 25 (the Little G Minor) begins. We see what the serva see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Salieri lies on the floor in a pool of blood, an open razor in his hand. He has cut his throat but is still ali He gestures at them. They run to him. Barely, we glimpse room - an old chair, old tables piled with books, a forte piano, a chamber-pot on the floor - as the Valet and the  Cook struggle to lift their old Master, and bind his blee throat with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five dancing couples, fifty guests, ten servants,  full orchestra. As the music slows a little, we see a Masquerade Ball in  progress. A crowded room of dancers is executing the slow portion of a dance fashionable in the early 1820's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the fast music returns, we see Old Salieri being carri out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants, and pl in a horse-drawn wagon under the supervision of a middle- aged doctor in a tall hat. This is DOCTOR GULDEN. He gets beside his patient. The driver whips up the horse, and th wagon dashes off through the still-falling snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon is galloping through the snowy streets of the c Inside the conveyance we see Old Salieri wrapped in blank half-conscious, being held by the hospital attendants. Do Gulden stares at him grimly. The wagon arrives outside th General Hospital of Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide, white-washed corridor. Doctor Gulden is walking d it with a priest, a man of about forty, concerned, but  somewhat self-important. This is Father VOGLER, Chaplain the hospital. In the corridor as they walk, we note sever patients -- some of them visibly disturbed mentally. All  patients wear white linen smocks. Doctor Gulden wears a d frock-coat; Vogler, a cassock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to live. It's much harder  to cut your throat than most people  imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop outside a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are. Do you wish me to come  in with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Doctor. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogler nods and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bare room - one of the best available in the General  Hospital. It contains a bed, a table with candles, chairs small forte-piano of the early nineteenth century. As Vog enters, Old Salieri is sitting in a wheel-chair, looking the window. His back is to us. The priest closes the door quietly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Salieri?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Salieri turns around to look at him. We see that his  throat is bandaged expertly. He wears hospital garb, and  over it the Civilian Medal and Chain with which we will l see the EMPEROR invest him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Father Vogler. I am a Chaplain  here. I thought you might like to  talk to someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tried to take your life. You do  remember that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the sight of God that is a sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand that you have  sinned? Gravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot leave alone a soul in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who I am? You never heard  of me, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes no difference. All men  are equal in God's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Offer me your confession. I can offer  you God's forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not seek forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son, there is something dreadful  on your soul. Unburden it to me. I'm  here only for you. Please talk to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How well are you trained in music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a little. I studied it in my  youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here in Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you must know this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He propels his wheelchair to the forte-piano, and plays a unrecognizable melody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say I do. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised you don't know. It was  a very popular tune in its day. I  wrote it. How about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays another tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one brought down the house when  we played it first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays it with growing enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the pretty soprano KATHERINA CAVALIERI, now about  twenty-four, dressed in an elaborate mythological Persian costume, singing on stage. She's near the end of a very f aria by Salieri. The audience applauds wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hands off  the keys) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I regret it is not too familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you recall no melody of mine? I  was the most famous composer in Europe  when you were still a boy. I wrote  forty operas alone. What about this  little thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slyly he plays the opening measure of Mozart's Eine Klein Nachtmusik. The priest nods, smiling suddenly, and hums a little with the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know that! That's charming!  I  didn't know you wrote that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't. That was Mozart. Wolfgang  Amadeus Mozart. You know who that  is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. The man you accuse yourself  of killing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah - you've heard that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All Vienna has heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ( eagerly) And do they believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very long pause. Salieri stares above the priest, seemi lost in his own private world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, my son, if you have  anything to confess, do it now!   Give yourself some peace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A further pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was murdered, Father! Mozart!   Cruelly murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost whispering) Yes? Did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Old Salieri turns to him, a look of extreme  innocence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my idol! I can't remember a  time when I didn't know his name!   When I was only fourteen he was  already famous. Even in Legnago -  the tiniest town in Italy - I knew  of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are twelve children and twenty adults in the square We see the fourteen-year-old Salieri blindfolded, playing game of Blindman's Bluff with other Italian children, run about in the bright sunshine and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was still playing childish games  when he was playing music for kings  and emperors. Even the Pope in Rome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the six-year-old MOZART, also blindfolded, seated a gilded chair on a pile of books, playing the harpsichor for the POPE and a suite of CARDINALS and other churchmen Beside the little boy stands LEOPOLD, his father, smirkin with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admit I was jealous when I heard  the tales they told about him. Not  of the brilliant little prodigy  himself, but of his father, who had  taught him everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piece finishes. Leopold lowers the lid of the harpsic and lifts up his little son to stand on it. Mozart remove the blindfold to show a pale little face with staring eye Both father and son bow. A Papal Chamberlain presents Leo with a gold snuff box whilst the cardinals decorously app Over this scene Old Salieri speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father did not care for music. He  wanted me only to be a merchant,  like himself. As anonymous as he  was. When I told how I wished I could  be like Mozart, he would say, Why?  Do you want to be a trained monkey?  Would you like me to drag you around  Europe doing tricks like a circus  freak? How could I tell him what  music meant to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serene music of the Italian Baroque - Pergolesi's Stabat  Mater - sung by a choir of boys with organ accompaniment. We see the outside of the 17th-century church sitting in wide landscape of Lombardy: sunlit fields, a dusty, white road, poplar trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music continues and swells. We see the twelve-year-ol Salieri seated between his plump and placid parents in th congregation, listening in rapture. His father is a heavy looking, self-approving man, obviously indifferent to the music. A large and austere Christ on the cross hangs over the altar. Candles burn below his image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even then a spray of sounded notes  could make me dizzy, almost to  falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy falls forward on his knees. So do his parents and the other members of the congregation. He stares up at Ch who stares back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whilst my father prayed earnestly to  God to protect commerce, I would  offer up secretly the proudest prayer  a boy could think of. Lord, make me  a great composer! Let me celebrate  your glory through music - and be  celebrated myself! Make me famous  through the world, dear God! Make me  immortal! After I die let people  speak my name forever with love for  what I wrote! In return I vow I will  give you my chastity - my industry,  my deepest humility, every hour of  my life. And I will help my fellow  man all I can. Amen and amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells to a crescendo. The candles flare. We se the Christ through the flames looking at the boy benignly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you know what happened? A  miracle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, a large cooked fish on a thick china plate. Camera pu back to show the Salieri family at dinner. Father Salieri sits at the head of the table, a napkin tucked into his c Mother Salieri is serving the fish into portions and hand them round. Two maiden aunts are in attendance, wearing b and of course the young boy. Father Salieri receives his  plate of fish and starts to eat greedily. Suddenly there a gasp - he starts to choke violently on a fish bone. All the women get up and crowd around him, thumping and pumme him, but it is in vain. Father Salieri collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he was dead. Just like that!  And my life changed forever. My mother  said, Go. Study music if you really  want to. Off with you! And off I  went as quick as I could and never  saw Italy again. Of course, I knew  God had arranged it all; that was  obvious. One moment I was a frustrated  boy in an obscure little town. The  next I was here, in Vienna, city of  musicians, sixteen years old and  studying under Gluck! Gluck, Father.  Do you know who he was? The greatest  composer of his time. And he loved  me! That was the wonder. He taught  me everything he knew. And when I  was ready, introduced me personally  to the Emperor! Emperor Joseph - the  musical king!  Within a few years I  was his court composer. Wasn't that  incredible? Imperial Composer to His  Majesty! Actually the man had no ear  at all, but what did it matter? He  adored my music, that was enough.  Night after night I sat right next  to the Emperor of Austria, playing  duets with him, correcting the royal  sight-reading. Tell me, if you had  been me, wouldn't you have thought  God had accepted your vow? And believe  me, I honoured it. I was a model of  virtue. I kept my hands off women,  worked hours every day teaching  students, many of them for free,  sitting on endless committees to  help poor musicians - work and work  and work, that was all my life. And  it was wonderful! Everybody liked  me. I liked myself. I was the most  successful musician in Vienna. And  the happiest. Till he came. Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: 1780'S
dialogues.text: A grand room crowded with guests. A small group of Gypsy  musicians is playing in the background. Thirteen members the Archbishop's orchestra - all wind players, complete w 18th-century wind instruments: elaborate-looking bassoons basset horns, etc. and wearing their employer's livery - laying out music on stands at one end of the room. At the other end is a large gilded chair, bearing the arms of th ARCHBISHOP OF SALZBURG. A throng of people is standing,  talking, and preparing to sit upon the rows of waiting ch to hear a concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day he came to Vienna to play  some of his music at the residence  of his employer, the Prince-Archbishop  of Salzburg. Eagerly I went there to  seek him out. That night changed my  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Salieri, age thirty-one, a neat, carefully turned- man in decent black clothes and clean white linen, walkin through the crowd of guests. We follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I went through the salon, I played  a game with myself. This man had  written his first concerto at the  age of four; his first symphony at  seven; a full-scale opera at twelve.   Did it show? Is talent like that  written on the face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see shots of assorted young men staring back at Salier as he moves through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of them could he be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the men recognize Salieri and bow respectfully. T suddenly a servant bearing a large tray of cakes and past stalks past. Instantly riveted by the sight of such delig Salieri follows him out of the Grand Salon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The servant marches along bearing his tray of pastries al Salieri follows him. The servant turns into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri's POV: several tables, dressed to the floor with  cloths are loaded with many plates of confectionery. It i in fact, Salieri's idea of paradise! The servant puts his tray down on one of the tables and withdraws from the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri turns away so as not to be noticed by the servant As soon as the man disappears, Salieri sneaks into the bu room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri enters the room and looks about him cautiously. H is salivating with anticipation as he stares at the feast sweet things. His attention is attracted in particular by huge pile of dark chocolate balls arranged in the shape o pineapple. He reaches out a hand to steal one of the ball but at the same moment he hears giggling coming toward hi He ducks down behind the pastry table. A girl - CONSTANZE - rushes into the room. She runs strai across it and hides herself behind one of the tables. After a beat of total silence, MOZART runs into the room, stops, and looks around. He is age twenty-six, wearing a  fine wig and a brilliant coat with the insignia of the  Archbishop of Salzburg upon it. He is puzzled; Constanze disappeared. Baffled, he turns and is about to leave the room, when  Constanze suddenly squeaks from under the cloth like a ti mouse. Instantly Mozart drops to all fours and starts cra across the floor, meowing and hissing like a naughty cat. Watched by an astonished Salieri, Mozart disappears under the cloth and obviously pounces upon Constanze. We hear a high-pitched giggle, which is going to characterize Mozar throughout the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The throng is mostly seated. The musicians are in their  places, holding their various exotic-looking wind instrum the candles are all lit. A Majordomo appears and bangs hi staff on the floor for attention. Immediately COLLOREDO,  Prince-Archbishop of Salzburg enters. He is a small self- important figure of fifty in a wig, surmounted by a scarl skullcap. He is followed by his Chamberlain, the Count AR Everyone stands. The Archbishop goes to his throne and si His guests sit also. Arco gives the signal to start the m Nothing happens. Instead, a wind musician gets up, approa the Chamberlain and whispers in his ear. Arco in turn whi to the Archbishop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're looking for him, Your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three servants are opening doors and looking into rooms g off the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests are turning around and looking at the Archbish The musicians are watching. There is puzzlement and a mur of comment. The Archbishop tightens his lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Arco) We'll start without him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is on his knees before the tablecloth, which reach to the floor. Under it is Constanze. We hear her giggling he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miaouw! Miaouw! Mouse-wouse? It's  Puss-wuss, fangs-wangs. Paws-claws.   Pounce-bounce!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs her ankle. She screams. He pulls her out by her  leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it. Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They roll on the floor. He tickles her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am! I am! I'm stopping it - slowly.   You see! Look, I've stopped. Now we  are going back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to drag her back under the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Back! Back! Listen - don't you  know where you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the Residence of the  Fartsbishop of Salzburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fartsbishop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs delightedly, then addresses an imaginary  Archbishop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Grace, I've got something to  tell you. I want to complain about  this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, tell him. Tell them all.   They won't understand you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because here everything goes  backwards. People walk backwards,  dance backwards, sing backwards, and  talk backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? People fart backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that's funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think it's brilliant. You've  been doing it for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a high pitched giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ha, ha, ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sra-I'm-sick! Sra-I'm sick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are. You're very sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Say it backwards, shit-wit.  Sra-I'm-sick Say it backwards!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working it out) Sra-I'm-sick. Sick - kiss I'm - my  Kiss my! Sra-I'm-sick - Kiss my arse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Em iram! Em iram!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not playing this game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is serious. Say it backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say it - you'll see. It's very  serious. Em iram!  Em iram!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iram - marry Em - marry me! No, no!   You're a fiend. I'm not going to  marry a fiend. A dirty fiend at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ui-vol-i-tub!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tub - but i-tub - but I vol - love  but I love ui - You. I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mood becomes suddenly softer. She kisses him. They  embrace. Then he spoils it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish-I'm tee. What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish-I'm-tee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat my - ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shocked, she strikes at him. At the same moment the music starts in the salon next door. We hear the opening of the Serenade for Thirteen Wind Instruments, K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My music! They've started! They've  started without me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaps up, disheveled and rumpled and runs out of the r Salieri watches in amazement and disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music is louder. Mozart hastens towards the Grand Sal away from the buffet room, adjusting his dress as he goes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opening of the Serenade is being tentatively conducte by the leader of the wind-musicians. Guests turn around a Mozart appears - bowing to the Archbishop - and walks wit an attempt at dignity to the dais where the wind band is  playing. The leader yields his place to the composer and  Mozart smoothly takes over conducting. Constanze, deeply embarrassed, sneaks into the room and s herself at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music fades down. Salieri stands shocked from his  inadvertent eavesdropping. After a second he moves almost a trance toward the door; the music dissolves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is conducting the Adagio from his Serenade (K. 361 guiding the thirteen wind instrumentalists. The squeezebo opening of the movement begins. Salieri appears at the do at the back of the salon. He stares in disbelief at Mozar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that was he! That giggling, dirty- minded creature I'd just seen crawling  on the floor. Mozart. The phenomenon  whose legend had haunted my youth.   Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells up and Salieri listens to it with eyes c amazed, transported - suddenly engulfed by the sound. Fin it fades down and away and changes into applause. Salieri opens his eyes. The audience is clearly delighted. Mozart bows to them, a delighted. Colloredo rises abruptly, and without looking Mozart or applauding and leaves the Salon. Count Arco  approaches the composer. Mozart turns to him, radiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me, please. The Archbishop  would like a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows Arco out of the room, through a throng of admi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart and Arco walk side by side. They pass Salieri who staring at Mozart in fascination. As they disappear, he s toward the music stands, unable to help himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think that went off remarkably  well, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These Viennese certainly know good  music when they hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Grace is very angry with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at the door of Colloredo's private apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are to come in here and ask his  pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arco opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Archbishop is sitting, chatting to quests. Among them are several ladies. Arco approaches him obsequiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Mozart. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why what, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I have to be humiliated in  front of my guests by one of my own  servants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humiliated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much provocation am I to endure  from you? The more license I allow  you, the more you take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company watches this scene, deeply interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If His Grace is not satisfied with  me, he can dismiss me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you to return immediately to  Salzburg. Your father is waiting for  you there patiently. I will speak to  you further when I come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Your Grace! I mean with all  humility, no. I would rather you  dismissed me. It's obvious I don't  satisfy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then try harder, Mozart. I have no  intention of dismissing you. You  will remain in my service and learn  your place. Go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hand to be kissed. Mozart does it with a  furious grace, then leaves the room. As he opens the door see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of people who have attended the concert, among th Constanze, are standing outside the private apartment. At sight of the composer they break into sustained applause. Mozart is suddenly delighted. He throws the door wide ope so that the guests can see into the private apartment whe the Archbishop sits - and he can see them. Colloredo is  clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee. He smiles and bows uneasily, as they include him in the smal ovation. Mozart stands in the corridor, out of the Archbishop's li of sight, bowing and giggling, and encouraging the applau for the Archbishop with conducting gestures. Suddenly  irritated, Colloredo signs to Arco, who steps forward and shuts the door, ending the applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri, in this vast room, is standing and looking at th full score of the Serenade. He turns the pages back to th slow movement. Instantly, we again hear its lyrical strai CU, Salieri, reading the score of the Adagio in helpless  fascination. The music is played against his description it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extraordinary! On the page it looked  nothing. The beginning simple, almost  comic. Just a pulse - bassoons and  basset horns - like a rusty  squeezebox. Then suddenly - high  above it - an oboe, a single note,  hanging there unwavering, till a  clarinet took over and sweetened it  into a phrase of such delight! This  was no composition by a performing  monkey! This was a music I'd never  heard. Filled with such longing,  such unfulfillable longing, it had  me trembling. It seemed to me that I  was hearing a voice of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the music snaps off. Mozart stands before him as lays down the score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the score, bows, and struts briskly out of the r Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little  figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Would God choose an obscene  child to be His instrument? It was  not to be believed! This piece had  to be an accident. It had to be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the table sits the EMPEROR JOSEPH II, eating his fruga dinner and sipping goat's milk. He is an intelligent, dap man of forty, wearing a military uniform. Around him but  standing, are his Chamberlain, JOHANN VON STRACK: stiff a highly correct. COUNT ORSINI-ROSENBERG: a corpulent man o sixty, highly conscious of his position as Director of th Opera. BARON VON SWIETEN, the Imperial Librarian: a grave but kindly and educated man in his mid-fifties. FIRST  KAPELLMEISTER GIUSEPPE BONNO: very Italian, cringing and  time-serving, aged about seventy. And Salieri, wearing  decorous black, as usual. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries, using quill pe and inkstands, write down everything of importance that i said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How good is he, this Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's remarkable, Majesty. I heard an  extraordinary serious opera of his  last month. Idomeneo, King of Crete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That? A most tiresome piece. I heard  it, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiresome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man trying to impress beyond  his abilities. Too much spice. Too  many notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, I thought it the most  promising work I've heard in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. Well then, we should make  some effort to acquire him. We could  use a good German composer in Vienna,  surely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree, Majesty, but I'm afraid  it's not possible. The young man is  still in the pay of the Archbishop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very small pay, I imagine. I'm sure  he could be tempted with the right  offer. Say, an opera in German for  our National Theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent, sire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not German, I beg your Majesty!  Italian is the proper language for  opera. All educated people agree on  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. What do you say, Chamberlain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my opinion, it is time we had a  piece in our own language, sir. Plain  German. For plain people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. Kapellmeister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Italian accent) Majesty, I must agree with Herr  Dirretore. Opera is an Italian art,  solamente. German is - scusate - too  bruta for singing, too rough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. Court Composer, what do you  say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is an interesting notion  to keep Mozart in Vienna, Majesty.  It should really infuriate the  Archbishop beyond measure - if that  is your Majesty's intention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are cattivo, Court Composer. (briskly, to Von Strack) I want to meet this young man.  Chamberlain, arrange a pleasant  welcome for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. There it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A somber room which serves both as a bedroom and a study. We see a four-poster bed. Also, a marble mantelpiece abov which hangs a handsome cross in olivewood, bearing the fi of a severe Christ. Opposite this image sits Salieri at h desk, on which stands a pile of music paper, quill pens a ink. On one side of him is an open forte-piano on which h occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing,  with some difficulty. He scratches notes out with his qui and ruffles his hair - which we see without a powdered wi There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A servant admits LORL, a young lower-class girl, who appe carrying a basket in which is a box covered with a napkin She has just come from the baker's shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Here she comes. Fraulein Lorl,  good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got for me today? Let  me see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greedily he unwraps the napkin and lifts the lid on the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha! Siena macaroons - my  favourites. Give my best thanks to  the baker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a biscuit and eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Are you well today,  Fraulein Lorl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bene! Bene!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives a little curtsey, flattered and giggling and is shown out. Salieri turns back to his work, chewing. He pl through a complete line of the march. He smiles, pleased  with the result.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie, Signore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He inclines his head to the Christ above the  fireplace, starts to play the whole march, including the phrase whic pleased him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The march continues on the forte-piano as we see Mozart,  seated in front of a mirror, wearing an extravagant wig. either side of him stands a SALESMAN, one of them holding another wig, equally extravagant. Mozart takes off the fi wig, to reveal his own blonde hair, of which he is extrem proud, and hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Salesman puts the second wig on his head. Mozart pull face of doubt in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it off and the other Salesman replaces it with t first wig on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they're both so beautiful, I  can't decide. Why don't I have two  heads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles. The music stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens. We glimpse in the next room the Emperor Jos bidding goodbye to a group of military officers standing  around a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and comes into the salon, where another group aw him. It consists of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Swieten and Salieri. The room contains several gilded cha dotted about, and a forte-piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All bow and say, Good morning, Your Majesty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Von Strack) Well, what do you have for me today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, Herr Mozart -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. Well. There it is. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, I hope you won't think it  improper, but I have written a little  March of Welcome in his honour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a charming idea. May I see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing it over) It's just a trifle, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I try it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Emperor goes to the instrument, sits and plays the fi bars of it. Quite well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delightful, Court Composer. Would  you permit me to play it as he comes  in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do me too much honour, Sire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have some fun. (to the waiting  Majordomo) Bring in Herr Mozart, please. But  slowly, slowly. I need a minute to  practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Majordomo bows and goes. The Emperor addresses himsel to the march. He plays a wrong note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-flat, Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking his instructions literally, the Majordomo is march very slowly toward the salon door. He is followed by a  bewildered Mozart, dressed very stylishly and wearing one the wigs from the perruqier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph finishes the march. The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart comes in eagerly. Immediately the march begins, pl by His Majesty. All the courtiers stand, listening with  admiration. Joseph plays well, but applies himself fierce to the manuscript. Mozart, still bewildered, regards the  scene, but does not seem to pay attention to the music it It finishes and all clap obsequiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo, Your Majesty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, Sire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Emperor rises, pleased with himself. He snatches the  manuscript off the stand and holds it in his hand for the rest of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, gentlemen, a little less  enthusiasm, I beg you. Ah, Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hand. Mozart throws himself to his knees, to Joseph's discomfort kisses the royal hand with fervour

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, please! It is not a holy  relic. (raising Mozart up) You know we have met already? In  this very room. Perhaps you won't  remember it, you were only six years  old. (to the others) He was giving the most brilliant  little concert here. As he got off  the stool, he slipped and fell. My  sister Antoinette helped him up  herself, and do you know what he  did? Jumped straight into her arms  and said, Will you marry me, yes or  no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassed, Mozart bursts into a wild giggle. Joseph hel him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know all these gentlemen, I'm  sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Von Strack and Bonno nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron Von Swieten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a great admirer of yours, young  man. Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director of our Opera. Count  Orsini-Rosenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing excitedly) Oh sir, yes! The honour is mine.   Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orsini-Rosenberg nods without enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here is our illustrious Court  Composer, Herr Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand) Finally! Such an immense joy. Diletto  straordinario!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know your work well, Signore. Do  you know I actually composed some  variations on a melody of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mio caro Adone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funny little tune, but it yielded  some good things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he has returned the  compliment. Herr Salieri composed  that March of Welcome for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking expertly) Really? Oh, grazie, Signore! Sono  commosso! E un onore per mo  eccezionale. Compositore brilliante  e famossissimo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows elaborately. Salieri inclines himself, dryly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there it is. Now to business.   Young man, we are going to commission  an opera from you. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the courtiers) Did we vote in the end for German or  Italian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually, Sire, if you remember,  we did finally incline to Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it was really decided,  Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, German! German! Please let it be  German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I've already found the most  wonderful libretto!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Have I seen it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I don't think you have, Herr  Director. Not yet. I mean, it's quite  n - Of course, I'll show it to you  immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what is it about? Tell us the  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's actually quite amusing, Majesty.   It's set - the  whole thing is set  in a - in a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops short with a little giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a Pasha's Harem, Majesty. A  Seraglio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean in Turkey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why especially does it have to  be in German?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well not especially. It can be in  Turkish, if you really want. I don't  care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles again. Orsini-Rosenberg looks at him sourly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kindly) My dear fellow, the language is not  finally the point. Do you really  think that subject is quite  appropriate for a national theatre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? It's charming. I mean, I  don't actually show concubines  exposing their! their! It's not  indecent! (to Joseph) It's highly moral, Majesty. It's  full of proper German virtues. I  swear it. Absolutely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Sire, but what do you  think these could be? Being a  foreigner, I would love to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cattivo again, Court Composer. Well,  tell him, Mozart. Name us a German  virtue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love, Sire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, love! Well of course in Italy we  know nothing about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Italian faction - Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno - laugh  discreetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think you do. I mean  watching Italian opera, all those  male sopranos screeching. Stupid fat  couples rolling their eyes about!  That's not love - it's just rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An embarrassed pause. Bonno giggles in nervous amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, you choose the language. It  will be my task to set it to the  finest music ever offered a monarch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Joseph is clearly pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there it is. Let it be German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods - he has wanted this result all the time. He turn and makes for the door. All bow. Then he becomes aware of the manuscript in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, this is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart does not take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it, Sire, if you want to. It is  already here in my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? On one hearing only?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so, Sire, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart bows and hands the manuscript back to the Emperor. Then he goes to the forte-piano and seats himself. The ot except for Salieri, gather around the manuscript held by King. Mozart plays the first half of the march with deadl accuracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Salieri) The rest is just the same, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays the first half again but stops in the middle of phrase, which he repeats dubiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That really doesn't work, does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the courtiers look at Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you try this? Wouldn't it be  just a little more -?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays another phrase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or this - yes, this! Better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays another phrase. Gradually, he alters the music s that it turns into the celebrated march to be used later The Marriage of Figaro, Non Piu Andrai. He plays it with  increasing abandon and virtuosity. Salieri watches with a fixed smile on his face. The court watches, astonished. H finishes in great glory, takes his hands off the keys wit gesture of triumph - and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the olivewood cross. Salieri is sitting at his des staring at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie, Signore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door. He does not hear it, but si on. Another knock, louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorl comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Cavalieri is here for her  lesson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHERINA CAVALIERI, a young, high-spirited soprano of tw is waiting for him, dressed in a fashionable dress and we on her head an exotic turban of satin, with a feather. Lo exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtseying to him) Maestro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (posing, in her turban) Well? How do you like it? It's  Turkish. My hairdresser tells me  everything's going to be Turkish  this year!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What else did he tell you  today? Give me some gossip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I heard you met Herr Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? News travels fast in Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's been commissioned to write  an opera. Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a part for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well even if there is, I don't think  you want to get involved with this  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do you know where it's set, my  dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a harem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brothel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Turkish brothel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turkish? Oh, if it's Turkish, that's  different. I want to be in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, it will hardly enhance your  reputation to be celebrated throughout  Vienna as a singing prostitute for a  Turk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seats himself at the forte-piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well perhaps you could introduce  us anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plays a chord. She sings a scale, expertly. He strikes another chord. She starts another scale, then breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might be disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks and talent don't always go  together, Katherina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (airily) Looks don't concern me, Maestro.   Only talent interests a woman of  taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strikes the chord again, firmly. Cavalieri sings her n scale, then another one, and another one, doing her exerc in earnest. As she hits a sustained high note the orchest accompaniment in the middle of Martern Aller Arten from I Seraglio comes in underneath and the music changes from  exercises to the exceedingly florid aria. We DISSOLVE on the singer's face, and she is suddenly not merely turbaned, but painted and dressed totally in a Tur manner, and we are on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heroine of the opera (Cavalieri) is in full cry addre the Pasha with scorn and defiance. The house is full. Watching the performance - which is  conducted by Mozart from the clavier in the midst of the  orchestra - we note Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno a Von Swieten, all grouped around the Emperor, in a box. In another box we see an overdressed, middle-aged woman a three girls, one of whom is Constanze. This is the formid MADAME WEBER and her three daughters, Constanze, JOSEFA a SOPHIE. All are enraptured by the spectacle and Madame We is especially enraptured by being there at all. Not so,  Salieri, who sits in another box, coldly watching the sta Cavalieri is singing Martern aller Arten from the line Do du bist entschlossen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you are determined, Since you  are determined, Calmly, with no  ferment, Welcome - every pain and  woe. Bind me then - compel me! Bind  me then - compel me! Hurt me. Break  me! Kill me! At last I shall be freed  by death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a few moments of this showy aria, with the composer and the singer staring at each other - he conducting  elaborately for her benefit, and she following his beat w rapturous eyes - the music fades, and Salieri speaks over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she was. I had no idea where  they met - or how - yet there she  stood on stage for all to see. Showing  off like the greedy songbird she  was. Ten minutes of ghastly scales  and arpeggios, whizzing up and down  like fireworks at a fairground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music up again for the last 30 bars of the aria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Be freed at last by death! Be freed  at last by death! At last I shall be  freed By! Death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the orchestral coda ends, cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see that night has fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understand, I was in love with the  girl. Or at least in lust. I wasn't  a saint. It took me the most  tremendous effort to be faithful to  my vow. I swear to you I never laid  a finger on her. All the same, I  couldn't bear to think of anyone  else touching her - least of all the  Creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brilliant Turkish finale of Seraglio bursts over us. All the cast is lined up on stage. Mozart is conducting w happy excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Pasha Selim May he Live forever!  Ever, ever, ever, ever! Honour to  his regal name! Honour to his regal  name! May his noble brow emblazon  Glory, fortune, joy and fame! Honour  be to Pasha Selim Honour to his regal  name! Honour to his regal name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains fall. Much applause. The Emperor claps vigor and - following his lead - so do the courtiers. The curta part. Mozart applauds the singers who applaud him back. H skips up onto the stage amongst them. The curtains fall a as they all bow. In the auditorium, the chandeliers desce filling it with light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are down, and an excited hubbub of singers i costume surround Mozart and Cavalieri, all excited and  chattering. Suddenly a hush. The Emperor is seen approach from the wings, lit by flunkies holding candles. Von Stra Orsini-Rosenberg and Von Swieten, amongst others, follow  him. Also Salieri. The singers line up. Joseph stops at  Cavalieri who makes a deep curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo, Madame. You are an ornament  to our stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Salieri) And to you, Court Composer. Your  pupil has done you great credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us pass, please! Let us pass at  once! We're with the Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, Madame. It is not  permitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who I am? (pointing to Constanze) This is my daughter. I am Frau Weber.  We are favoured guests!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, Madame, but I have my  orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Herr Mozart! You call Herr Mozart  immediately! This is insupportable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Constanze. Just ignore  this fellow. (pushing her) Go ahead, dear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barring the way) I am sorry, Madame, but no! I cannot  let anyone pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, I am no stranger to  theatres. I'm no stranger to  insolence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All are applauding Cavalieri. The Emperor turns to Mozart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Herr Mozart! A good effort.  Decidedly that. An excellent effort!   You've shown us something quite new  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart bows frantically: he is over-excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is new, it is, isn't it, Sire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And German?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Absolutely. German.   Unquestionably!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then you like it? You really like  it, Your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do. It's very good. Of  course now and then - just now and  then - it gets a touch elaborate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Sire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I mean occasionally it seems  to have, how shall one say? (he stops in  difficulty; to Orsini- Rosenberg) How shall one say, Director?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too many notes, Your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Very well put. Too many  notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. There are just  as many notes, Majesty, as are  required. Neither more nor less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear fellow, there are in fact  only so many notes the ear can hear  in the course of an evening. I think  I'm right in saying that, aren't I,  Court Composer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! yes! er, on  the whole, yes,  Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Salieri) But this is absurd!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, young man, don't take it  too hard. Your work is ingenious.  It's quality work. And there are  simply too many notes, that's all.  Cut a few and it will be perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which few did you have in mind,  Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. General embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. There it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into this uncomfortable scene bursts a sudden eruption of noise and Madame Weber floods onto the stage, followed by her daughters. All turn to look at this amazing spectacle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi! Wolfi, my dear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves toward Mozart with arms outstretched in an absu theatrical gesture, then sees the Emperor. She stares at  him, mesmerized, her mouth open, unable even to curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart moves forward quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, this is Madame Weber. She  is my landlady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enchanted, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Sire! such an honour! And, and,  and these are my dear daughters.   This is Constanze. She is the fiancee  of Herr Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze curtsies. CU, of Cavalieri, astonished at the n CU, of Salieri, watching her receive it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? How delightful. May I ask  when you marry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - Well we haven't quite received  my father's consent, Your Majesty.   Not entirely. Not altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my advice is to marry this  charming young lady and stay with us  in Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? You see? I've told him that,  Your Majesty, but he won't listen to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavalieri is glaring at Mozart. Mozart looks hastily away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Your Majesty, you give such  wonderful - such impeccable - such  royal advice. I - I - May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She attempts to kiss the royal hand, but faints instead. The Emperor contemplates her prone body and steps back a  pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. There it is. Strack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods pleasantly to all and leaves the stage, with his  Chamberlain. All bow. Cavalieri turns with a savage look at Mozart and leaves t stage the opposite way, to her dressing room, tossing her plumed head. Salieri watches. Mozart stays for a second,  indecisive whether to follow the soprano or help Madame W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mozart) Get some water!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries away. The daughters gather around Madame Weber

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherina sits fuming at her mirror. A dresser is taking pins out of her wig as she stares straight ahead of her.  Mozart sticks his head round the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherina! I'll tell you what I'm  going to do. I'm going to write  another aria for you. Something even  more amazing for the second act. I  have to get some water. Her mother  is lying on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dashes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze and Mozart make their way quickly through a cro of actors in turbans and caftans, and stagehands carrying bits of the dismantled set of Seraglio. We see all the tu of backstage after a performance. A fireman passes Mozart carrying a small bucket of water. Mozart snatches it from him and pushes his way through th crowd to Madame Weber, who still lies prone on the stage. Mozart pushes through the crowd surrounding her and throw water on her face. She is instantly revived by the shock. Constanze assists her to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of being furious, Madame Weber smiles at them  rapturously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, what an evening! What a wise man  we have for an Emperor. Oh, my  children! (with sudden, hard  briskness) Now I want you to write your father  exactly what His Majesty said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The activity continues to swirl around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should really go home now, Frau  Weber. Your carriage must be waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But aren't you taking us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to the singers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right; we'll wait for  you. Just don't take all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cavalieri, still in costume, is marching up and down, ver agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know? Had you heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marriage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what does it matter to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! He can marry who he pleases.  I don't give a damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She catches him looking at her and tries to compose herse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I? Tell me honestly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were sublime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think of the music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extremely clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning you didn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart comes in unexpectedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is her mother still lying on the  floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seats herself at her mirror and removes her wig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Mozart, my sincere  congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you like it, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really is the best music one can  hear in Vienna today. Don't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she a good fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume she's the virtuoso in that  department. There can't be any other  reason you'd marry someone like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri looks astonished. There is a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Constanze enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Wolfi. Mama is not feeling  very well. Can we leave now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. You can't take him  away now. This is his night. Won't  you introduce us, Wolfgang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us, Fraulein. Good night,  Signore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart hurries Constanze out of the door. Cavalieri looks after them as they go, her voice breaking and rising out control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are full of surprises,  aren't you? You are quite  extraordinary, you little shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and collapses, crying with rage, into Salieri's arms. We focus on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment I knew beyond any  doubt. He'd had her. The Creature  had had my darling girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man speaks passionately to the priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was incomprehensible. What was  God up to? Here I was denying all my  natural lust in order to deserve  God's gift and there was Mozart  indulging his in all directions -  even though engaged to be married! -  and no rebuke at all! Was it possible  I was being tested? Was God expecting  me to offer forgiveness in the face  of every offense, no matter how  painful? That was very possible. All  the same, why him? Why use Mozart to  teach me lessons in humility? My  heart was filling up with such hatred  for that little man. For the first  time in my life I began to know really  violent thoughts. I couldn't stop  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day. Sometimes for hours I  would pray!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Please! Send him away, back  to Salzburg. For his sake as well as  mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Christ staring from the Cross.

dialogues.speaker: 1780'S
dialogues.text: We see Leopold kneeling now not to the Cross but to Archb Colloredo, sitting impassively on his throne. Count Arco  stands beside him. Leopold is a desperate, once-handsome of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I won't have him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he needs to be here in Salzburg,  Your Grace. He needs me and he needs  you. Your protection, your  understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sir, yes! He's about to make the  worst mistake of his life. Some little  Viennese slut is trying to trick him  into marriage. I know my son. He is  too simple to see the trap - and  there is no one there who really  cares for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised. Money seems to be  more important to him than loyalty  or friendship. He has sold himself  to Vienna. Let Vienna look out for  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son is an unprincipled, spoiled,  conceited brat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, that's the truth. But don't  blame him. The fault is mine. I was  too indulgent with him. But not again.   Never again, I promise! I implore  you - let me bring him back here.  I'll make him give his word to serve  you faithfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how will you make him keep it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sir, he's never disobeyed me in  anything. Please, Your Grace, give  him one more chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have leave to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Your Grace - I thank Your Grace!   I thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In deepest gratitude he kisses the Archbishop's hand. He  motions Leopold to rise. We hear the first dark fortissim chord which begins the Overture to Don Giovanni: the them associated with the character of the Commendatore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second fortissimo chord sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a huge CU, of Mozart's head, looking front and dow as if reading his father's letter. We hear Leopold's voic over this image, no longer whining and anxious, but  impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I write to you with urgent news. I  am coming to Vienna. Take no further  steps toward marriage until we meet.  You are too gullible to see your own  danger. As you honour the father who  has devoted his entire life to yours,  do as I bid, and await my coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera pulls back to see that he is in fact kneeling  beside Constanze. A PRIEST faces them. Behind them are Ma Weber, Josefa and Sophie Weber, and a very few others. Am them, a merry looking lady in bright clothes: the BARONES WALDSTADTEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will you, Constanze Weber, take  this man, Wolfgang to be your lawful  husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I now pronounce you man and wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opening kyrie of the great Mass in C Minor is heard. Mozart and Constanze kiss. They are in tears. Madame Webe and her daughters look on approvingly. The music swells a continues under the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a view of a castle in background. Leopold sits a in his room. He is reading a letter from Wolfgang. At his feet are his trunks, half-packed for the journey he will now take. We hear Mozart's voice reading the following le and we see, as the camera roves around the room, mementos the young prodigy's early life: the little forte-piano ma for him; the little violin made for him; an Order present to him. We see a little starling in a wicker cage. And we see portraits of the boy on the walls, concluding with th familiar family portrait of Wolfgang and his sister Nanne seated at the keyboard with Leopold standing, and the pic of their mother on the wall behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most beloved father, it is done. Do  not blame me that I did not wait to  see your dear face. I knew you would  have tried to dissuade me from my  truest happiness and I could not  have borne it. Your every word is  precious to me. Remember how you  have always told me Vienna is the  City of Musicians. To conquer here  is to conquer Europe! With my wife I  can do it.  I vow I will become  regular in my habits and productive  as never before. She is wonderful,  Papa, and I know that you will love  her. And one day soon when I am a  wealthy man, you will come and live  with us, and we will be so happy. I  long for that day, best of Papas,  and kiss your hand a hundred thousand  times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music of the Mass fades as Leopold crumples the lette in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri stands waiting, hat in hand. Beside him stands a  royal servant. Behind him, gardeners are glimpsed tending the shrubs and bushes along a grassy ride. Down this ride are seen cantering two people on horseback: the Emperor J and his niece, the PRINCESS ELIZABETH. They are mounted o glossy horses. The Princess rides side-saddle. Running be her is a panting groom. The Emperor rides elegantly; his  niece, a dumpy little Hapsburg girl of sixteen, like a sa of potatoes. As they draw level with Salieri they stop, a the groom holds the head of the Princess' horse. Salieri  bows respectfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Court Composer. This  is my niece, the Princess Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of breath, the Princess nods nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has asked me to advise her on a  suitable musical instructor. I think  I've come up with an excellent idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
