dialogues.text: He smiles at Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Your Majesty, it would be such a  tremendous honour!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking about Herr Mozart.   What is your view?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri's face falls, almost imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An interesting idea, Majesty. But -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already commissioned an opera  from Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the result satisfies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. My concern is to  protect you from any suspicion of  favouritism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. Favouritism. But I so want  Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure there is a way, Majesty.  Some kind of a little contest. I  could perhaps put together a small  Committee, and I could see to it  naturally that it will select  according to Your Majesty's wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You please me, Court Composer. A  very clever idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing) Sire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. There it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rides on. The groom releases her horse's head, and run on after the Princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Von Strack sits stiffly behind his gilded desk. Mozart st before him, trembling with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Herr Chamberlain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I have to submit samples of  my work to some stupid committee?   Just to teach a sixteen-year-old  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because His Majesty wishes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the Emperor angry with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why doesn't he simply appoint  me to the post?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart, you are not the only composer  in Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I'm the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little modesty would suit you  better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is on this committee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kapellmeister Bonno, Count Orsini- Rosenberg and Court Composer Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally, the Italians! Of course!   Always the Italians!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hate my music. It terrifies  them. The only sound Italians  understand is banality. Tonic and  dominant, tonic and dominant, from  here to Resurrection! (singing angrily) Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Anything  else is morbid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show them one interesting modulation  and they faint. Ohime! Morbidezza!   Morbidezza! Italians are musical  idiots and you want them to judge my  music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, young man, the issue is simple.  If you want this post, you must submit  your stuff in the same way as all  your colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must I? Well, I won't! I tell you  straight: I will not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is very small and untidy. Constanze is marching and down it, upset. Mozart is lying on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're mad! You're really  mad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One royal pupil and the whole of  Vienna will come flocking. We'd be  set up for life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll come anyway. They love me  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they will not. I know how things  work in this city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes? You always know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not borrowing any more  money from my mother, and that's  that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You borrowed money from your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't do that again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we going to live, Wolfi? Do  you want me to go into the streets  and beg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All they want to see is your work.   What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Just shut up! I don't need  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't pride. It's sheer  stupidity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glares at him, almost in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri is giving a lesson to a girl student, who is sing the Italian art song, Caro Mio Ben. There is a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERVANT enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, there is a lady who  insists on talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't say. But she says it's  urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the pupil) Excuse me, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri goes into the salon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze stands, closely veiled, holding a portfolio stu with manuscripts. The singing lesson ends, with two chord on the instrument. Salieri enters the salon. Constanze dr him a shy curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellency!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame. How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shyly, she unveils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frau Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Your Excellency. I've  come on behalf of my hus band. I'm -  I'm bringing some samples of his  work so he can be considered for the  royal appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How charming.  But why did he not  come himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's terribly busy, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the portfolio and puts it on a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will look at them, of course, the  moment I can. It will be an honour.   Please give him my warmest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it be too much trouble, sir,  to ask you to look at them now?   While I wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm not at leisure this  very moment. Just leave them with  me. I assure you they will be quite  safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I really cannot do that, Your  Excellency. You see, he doesn't know  I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband is a proud man, sir. He  would be furious if he knew I'd come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he didn't send you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. This is my own idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we really need this job. We're  desperate. My husband spends far  more than he can ever earn. I don't  mean he's lazy - he's not at all -  he works all day long. It's just!  he's not practical. Money simply  slips through his fingers, it's really  ridiculous, Your Excellency. I know  you help musicians. You're famous  for it. Give him just this one post.   We'd be forever indebted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me offer you some refreshment.   Do you know what these are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cappezzoli di Venere. Nipples of  Venus. Roman chestnuts in brandied  sugar. Won't you try one? They're  quite surprising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers her the dish. She takes one and puts it in her  mouth. He watches carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! They're wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes one himself. We notice on his finger a heavy gol signet-ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't keep calling me that. It puts  me at such a distance. I was not  born a Court Composer, you know.   I'm from a small town, just like  your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her. She takes another chestnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you can't leave that  music, and come back again? I have  other things you might like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very tempting, but it's  impossible, I'm afraid. Wolfi would  be frantic if he found those were  missing. You see, they're all  originals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Originals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. He puts out his hand and takes up the portfolio  from the table. He opens it. He looks at the music. He is puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are originals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He doesn't make copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man faces the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Astounding! It was actually beyond  belief. These were first and only  drafts of music yet they showed no  corrections of any kind. Not one.   Do you realize what that meant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogler stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd simply put down music already  finished in his head. Page after  page of it, as if he was just taking  dictation. And music finished as no  music is ever finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, The manuscript in Mozart's handwriting. The music beg to sound under the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Displace one note and there would be  diminishment. Displace one phrase,  and the structure would fall. It was  clear to me. That sound I had heard  in the Archbishop's palace had been  no accident. Here again was the very  voice of God! I was staring through  the cage of those meticulous ink- strokes at an absolute, inimitable  beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells. What we now hear is an amazing collage great passages from Mozart's music, ravishing to Salieri to us. The Court Composer, oblivious to Constanze, who si happily chewing chestnuts, her mouth covered in sugar, wa around and around his salon, reading the pages and droppi them on the floor when he is done with them. We see his  agonized and wondering face: he shudders as if in a rough and tumbling sea; he experiences the point where beauty a great pain coalesce. More pages fall than he can read,  scattering across the floor in a white cascade, as he cir the room. Finally, we hear the tremendous Qui Tollis from the Mass C Minor. It seems to break over him like a wave and, unab to bear any more of it, he slams the portfolio shut.  Instantly, the music breaks off, reverberating in his hea He stands shaking, staring wildly. Constanze gets up,  perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it no good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is miraculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. He's really proud of his  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, will you help him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri tries to recover himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night I dine with the  Emperor. One word from me and the  post is his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overjoyed, she stops and kisses his hand. He raises her - and then clasps her to him clumsily. She pushes herself a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some service deserves service in  return. No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it obvious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at one another: Constanze in total disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a post all Vienna seeks. If you  want it for your husband, come  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But! I'm a married woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't. It's up to you. Not to  be vague, that is the price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rings a silver bell for a servant and abruptly leaves roam. Constanze stares after him, horrified. The servant enters. Shocked and stunned, Constanze goes d an her knees and starts picking up the music from the flo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Father Vogler, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Father. Yes! So much for my vow  of chastity. What did it matter?  Good, patient, hard-working, chaste -  what did it matter? Had goodness  made me a good composer? I realized  it absolutely then - that moment:  goodness is nothing in the furnace  of art. And I was nothing to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying out) You cannot say that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Was Mozart a good man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God's ways are not yours. And you  are not here to question Him. Offer  him the salt of penitence. He will  give you back the bread of eternal  life. He is all merciful. That is  all you need to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I ever wanted was to sing to  Him. That's His doing, isn't it? He  gave me that longing - then made me  mute. Why? Tell me that. If He didn't  want me to serve Him with music, why  implant the desire, like a lust in  my body, then deny me the talent? Go  on, tell me! Speak for Him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son, no one can speak for God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? I thought you did so every day.   So speak now. Answer me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not claim to unravel the  mysteries. I treasure them. As you  should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Oh yes, yes, yes, yes, yes! Always  the same stale answers! (intimately to the  priest) There is no God of Mercy, Father.  Just a God of torture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri sits at his desk, staring up at the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening came to that room. I sat  there not knowing whether the girl  would return or not. I prayed as I'd  never prayed before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God, enter me now. Fill me with  one piece of true music. One piece  with your breath in it, so I know  that you love me. Please. Just one.  Show me one sign of your favour, and  I will show mine to Mozart and his  wife. I will get him the royal  position, and if she comes, I'll  receive her with all respect and  send her home in joy. Enter me! Enter  me! Please! Te imploro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long, long silence. Salieri stares at the cross. Christ s back at him impassively. Finally in this silence we hear faint knocking at the door. Salieri stirs himself. A serv appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That lady is back, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show her in. Then go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Servant bows and leaves. We follow him through:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Servant crosses it and enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze is sitting on an upright chair, veiled as befor the portfolio of music on her lap. Through the far door  leading from the hall, another servant is peering at her. The first servant joins him and shuts the door on the gir leaving her alone. We stay with her. The clock ticks on the mantelpiece. We  hear an old carriage pass in the street below. Nervously lifts her veil and looks about her. Suddenly Salieri appears from the music room. He is pale very tight. They regard each other. She smiles and rises greet him, affecting a relaxed and warm manner, as if to him at his ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm here. My husband has gone  to a concert. He didn't think I would  enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do apologize for this afternoon.   I behaved like a silly girl. Where  shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we stay here? It's a charming  room. I love these candlesticks.  Were they here earlier? I didn't  notice them I suppose I was too  nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she talks, she extinguishes the candles in a pair of  Venetian candelabra and subsequently other candles around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfgang was given some candlesticks  by King George in England, but they  were only wood. Oh, excuse me. Let's  not talk about him. What do you think  of this? It's real lace. Brussels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and takes off her shawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's much too good for every  day. I keep saying to Wolfi, don't  be so extravagant. Presents are  lovely, but we can't afford them.   It doesn't do any good. The more I  tell him, the more he spends. Oh,  excuse me! There I go again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the portfolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still want to look at this?  Or don't we need to bother anymore?   I imagine we don't, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him inquiringly, and drops the portfolio on floor; pages of music pour out of it. Instantly we hear a massive chord, and the great Qui Tollis from the Mass in Minor fills the room. To its grand and weighty sound,  Constanze starts to undress, watched by the horrified Sal Between him and her, music is an active presence, hurting and baffling him. He opens his mouth in distress. The mus pounds in his head. The candle flickers over her as she  removes her clothes and prepares for his embrace. Suddenl he cries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! Go! Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snatches up the bell and shakes it frantically, not  stopping until the two servants we saw earlier appear at door. The music stops abruptly. They stare at the appalle and frightened Constanze, who is desperately trying to co her nakedness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show this woman out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze hurls herself at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shit! You shit! You rotten shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seizes her wrists and thrusts her back. Then he leaves the room quickly, slamming the door behind him. Constanze turns and sees the two servants goggling at her in the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you staring at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wildly, she picks up the candelabrum and throws it at the It shatters on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Salieri standing, his eyes shut, shaking in distress. He opens them and sees Christ across the room, staring at him from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on, we are enemies, You and  I!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man is reliving the experience. Vogler looks at h horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because You will not enter me, with  all my need for you; because You  scorn my attempts at virtue; because  You choose for Your instrument a  boastful, lustful, smutty infantile  boy and give me for reward only the  ability to recognize the Incarnation;  because You are unjust, unfair,  unkind, I will block You! I swear  it! I will hinder and harm Your  creature on earth as far as I am  able. I will ruin Your Incarnation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, the fireplace. In it lies the olivewood Christ on the cross, burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What use after all is Man, if not to  teach God His lessons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cross flames up and disintegrates. Salieri stares at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door bursts open. Mozart stumbles in, followed EMMANUEL SCHIKANEDER, three young actresses, and another  man, all fairly drunk. Schikaneder (who appears everywher accompanied by young girls) is a large, fleshy, extravaga man of about thirty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanzi! Stanzi! Stanzi-Manzi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Mozart) Stanzi-Manzi-Banzi-Wanzi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh! Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks unsteadily to the bedroom door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the girls, very  tipsy) Sssh! You're dishgrashful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze lies in bed, her back turned to her husband, wh comes into the room and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playfully) Stanzi? How's my mouse? Mouse-wouse?   I'm back - puss-wuss is back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns around abruptly. She looks dreadful; her eyes r with weeping. Mozart is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanzi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He approaches the bed and sits on it. Immediately she sta crying again, desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? What is it?   Stanzi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her and she clings to him in a fierce embrace, c a flood of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it now. Stop it. I've brought  some friends to meet you. They're  next door waiting. Do we have anything  to eat? They're all starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them to go away. I don't want  to see anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them to go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh. What is it? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you! I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts crying again, throwing her arms around his nec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. Please stay with me. I'm  frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph sits eating. A butler serves him goat's milk to dr Joseph is holding a memorandum from Salieri in his hand. Salieri stands before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand me,  Court Composer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, I did. Believe me, it was a  most agonizing. decision. But finally,  I simply could not recommend Herr  Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Sire, I made some inquiries in  a routine way. I was curious to know  why he had so few pupils. It is rather  alarming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a gesture Joseph dismisses the butler, who bows and  leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, I don't like to talk against  a fellow musician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you, Mozart is not  entirely to be trusted alone with  young ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, one of my own  pupils - a very young singer - told  me she was - er - well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molested, Majesty. Twice, in the  course of the same lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. Well. There it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri has just returned from the palace and is coming u the staircase. He is met by his servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there is a Herr Mozart waiting  for you in the salon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri is plainly alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't say, sir. I told him I  didn't know when you would be back,  but he insisted on waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me. And stay in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mounts the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is waiting for Salieri, holding a portfolio. Salie approaches him nervously. Mozart stands not belligerently but humbly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart, what brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Excellency, you requested some  specimens of my work. Here they are.   I don't have to tell you how much I  need your help. I truly appreciate  your looking at these. I have  pressures on me - financial pressures.  As you know, I'm a married man now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are. How is your pretty wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is well. She is - well, actually,  I'm about to become a father! She  only told me last night. You are the  first to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm flattered. And congratulations  to you, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you see, this post is very  important to me right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri looks at him in distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you come to me yesterday,  Mozart? This is a most painful  situation. Yesterday I could have  helped you. Today, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Here is the music. It's here.   I am submitting it humbly. Isn't  that what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have just come from the palace.   The post has been filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filled? That's impossible! They  haven't even seen my work. I need  this post. Please, can't you help  me? Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Mozart, there is no one in  the world I would rather help, but  now it is too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whom did they choose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Sommer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sommer? Herr Sommer? But the man's a  fool! He's a total mediocrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no: he has yet to achieve  mediocrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't lose this post, I simply  can't! Excellency, please. Let's go  to the palace, and you can explain  to the Emperor that Herr Sommer is  an awful choice. He could actually  do musical harm to the Princess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An implausible idea. Between you and  me, no one in the world could do  musical harm to the Princess  Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart chuckles delightedly. Salieri offers him a glass o white dessert and a spoon. Mozart takes it absently and g on talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I must have pupils. Without  pupils I can't manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean to tell me you are  living in poverty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I'm broke. I'm always broke.   I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been said, my friend, that  you are inclined to live somewhat  above your means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can anyone say that? We have no  cook, no maid. We have no footman.   Nothing at all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that possible? You give  concerts, don't you? I hear they are  quite successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're stupendously successful.   You can't get a seat. The only problem  is none will hire me. They all want  to hear me play, but they won't let  me teach their daughters. As if I  was some kind of fiend. I'm not a  fiend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, could you lend me some money  till you have one? Then I'll teach  her for free. That's a promise. Oh,  I'm sorry. I'm being silly. Papa's  right - I should put a padlock on my  mouth. Seriously, is there any chance  you could manage a loan? Only for  six months, eight at most. After  that I'll be the richest man in  Vienna. I'll pay you back double.   Anything. Name your terms. I'm not  joking. I'm working on something  that's going to explode like a bomb  all over Europe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, how exciting! Tell me more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better not. It's a bit of a  secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come, Mozart; I'm interested.   Truly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's a big secret. Oh,  this is delicious! What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cream cheese mixed with granulated  sugar and suffused with rum. Crema  al Mascarpone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Italian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. We all have patriotic  feelings of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand, two hundred florins is  all I need A hundred? Fifty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly are you working on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say. Really

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you should become known  in Vienna as a debtor, Mozart.  However, I know a very distinguished  gentleman I could recommend to you.   And he has a daughter. Will that do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hysterical barking and howling. The hall is full of dogs, least five, all jumping up and dashing about and making a terrific racket. Mozart, dandified in a new coat and a pl hat for the occasion, has arrived to teach at the house o prosperous merchant, MICHAEL SCHLUMBERG. Bluff, friendly coarse-looking, he stands in his hall amidst the leaping barking animals, greeting Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet! Quiet! Quiet! Down there,  damn you. (to Mozart) Welcome to you. Pay no attention,  they're impossible. Stop it, you  willful things! Come this way. Just  ignore them. They're perfectly  harmless, just willful. I treat them  just like my own children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And which one of them do you want me  to teach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Ha-ha! That's funny - I like  it. Which one, eh? You're a funny  fellow. (shouting) Hannah! Come this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads Mozart through the throng of dogs into a salon  furnished with comfortable middle-class taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRAU SCHLUMBERG appears: an anxious woman in middle life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mozart) You won't be teaching this one either.   She's my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing) Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Herr Mozart, my dear. The  young man Herr Salieri recommended  to teach our Gertrude. Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gertrude!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be Herr Mozart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it's him. Who do you think  it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard about you for ages! I  thought you must be an old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gertrude!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such an honour for us to have  you here, Herr Mozart. And for  Gertrude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who know say the girl's got  talent. You must judge for yourself.   If you think she stinks, say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, please! I'm sure you will  find her most willing, Herr Mozart.   She's really very excited. She's  been preparing all morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, now! Here she comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERTRUDE SCHLUMBERG appears in the doorway: an awkward gi of fifteen in her best dress, her hair primped and curled She is exceedingly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Fraulein Schlumberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strudel, this is Herr Mozart. Say  good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gertrude giggles instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mozart) Perhaps a little refreshment first?  A little coffee, or a little  chocolate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like a little wine, if you have  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite right. He's going to need it. (calling and clapping  his hands) Klaus! A bottle of wine. Prestissimo!  Now let's go to it. I've been waiting  all day for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads the way into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A forte-piano is open and waiting. All the dogs follow hi After them come Mozart Frau and Fraulein Schlumberg. To  Mozart's dismay, husband and wife seat themselves quite  formally on a little narrow sofa, side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the dogs) Now sit down all of you and behave.  Zeman, Mandi, absolutely quiet! (to a young beagle) Especially you, Dudelsachs - not one  sound from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs settle at their feet. Husband and wife smile  encouragingly at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, then. Up and at it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart gestures to the music bench. Reluctantly, the girl sits at the instrument. Mozart sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, please play me something. Just  to give me an idea. Anything will  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to parents) I don't want you to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, dear. Just go ahead,  as if we weren't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, Strudel. It's part of  music, getting used to an audience.  Aren't I right, Herr Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes! on the whole. I suppose. (to Gertrude) How long have you been playing,  Fraulein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was your teacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was. But she quite outgrew the  little I could show her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Madame. (to Gertrude) Come on now - courage. Play me  something you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In response the wretched girl just stares down at the key without playing a note. An awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it would be better if we  were left alone. I think we're both  a little shy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Husband and wife look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Strudel's not shy. She's  just willful! You give into her now,  you'll be sorry later. Strudel -  play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The girl sits unmoving. Schlumberg bellows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said play!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if I were to play a little  first, it might encourage the  Fraulein. (to the girl) Why don't you let me try the  instrument? All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the girl rises. Mozart smiles at the parents. Th smile nervously back. Mozart slides along the bench, rais his hands and preludes over the keys. Instantly a dog how loudly. Startled, Mozart stops. Schlumberg leaps to his f and goes over to the beagle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that, Dudelsachs! Stop it at  once! (to Mozart) Don't let him disturb you. He'll be  all right. He's just a little willful  too. Please, please - play. I beg  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart resumes playing. This time it is a lively piece,  perhaps the Presto Finale from the K. 450. The dog howls  immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! STOP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not you. I was talking to the  dog. You keep playing. It's most  important. He always howls when he  hears music. We've got to break them  of the habit. Play, please. Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazed, Mozart starts to play the Rondo again. The dog ho louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. Now keep going, just keep  going. (to the beagle) Now you stop that noise, Dudelsachs,  you stop it this instant! This  instant, do you hear me? Keep going,  Herr Mozart, that's it. Go on, go  on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart plays on. Suddenly the dog falls silent. Schlumber smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good, good! Very good dog!  Very, very good Dudelsachs. (to his wife, snapping  his fingers) Quick, quick, dear, bring his biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife scurries to get a jar of biscuits. A servant bri in an open bottle of wine and a full glass on a tray. He  puts it down beside Mozart as Schlumberg addresses the si dog with deepest affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now guess who's going to get a nice  reward? Clever, clever Dudi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the biscuit to the dog who swallows it greedily. Mozart stops playing and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a miracle, Herr Mozart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely controlling  himself) Well, I'm a good teacher. The next  time you wish me to instruct another  of your dogs, please let me know.   Goodbye, Fraulein, goodbye, Madame!  goodbye, Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows to them and leaves the room. They look after him puzzled astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a strange young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He is a little strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheerful scene. We see Mozart strutting and beaming, ma his way through the crowd of porters, carriers and hawker sellers of sausages and pastries, vendors of hats and rib Horses and carriage clatter past him. His mood is best  expressed by a bubbling version of Non piu Andrai played the forte-piano. Still in the same mood, he enters the door of his own hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, he stops. He looks up the stairs. The grim open chords from the Overture to Don Giovanni cut across the m from Figaro. What he sees, looking up the stairs, is a  menacing figure in a long, grey cape and dark grey hat,  standing on the landing. The light comes from behind the  figure so that we see only its silhouette as it unfolds i arms towards Mozart in an alarming gesture of possession. It takes a beat in which the air of sinister mystery is h before Mozart realizes who it is. Then, as the music  continues, he hastily sets down the bottle of wine and ru joyfully up the stairs and hurls himself into the figure' arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa! PAPA!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men embrace. The music slowly fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cramped, low-ceilinged little room which nobody has tid for ages. We see music lying everywhere. Also there are m empty wine bottles; musical instruments - among them a  mandolin, a viola, a forte-piano with the black and white keys reversed - books and abandoned plates of food. Mozart clasps his father's arms. Leopold is now seen as a aging, travel-stained man in clothes that need repair. Hi face is lined, and he is obviously not in perfect health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I not welcome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, welcome! Welcome ten  thousand times. Papa! my Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very thin. Does she not feed  you, this wife of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart ducks away and fetches his father's bags from the  landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feed? Well, of course she feeds me.  She stuffs me like a goose all day  long. She's the best cook in the  world. I mean, since Mama. Just wait,  you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she not here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Stanzi? Stanzi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leopold looks about him at the mess in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always live like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Oh, I mean no - not exactly  like this. I mean today - just today,  Stanzi - I remember now. She had to  go - yes! She had to help her mother.  Yes, she's like that. Her mother's a  very sweet woman, you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries the bag across the room and opens the door of bedroom. Constanze lies in bed. She sits up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! I didn't know you were home.   Stanzi, this is my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze, who looks ill and tired, stares at Leopold.   Leopold stares back from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll wait, we'll wait. Why don't  you get up now, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very tired, poor creature.   You know me: I'm a real pig. It's  not so easy cleaning up after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have a maid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh we could, if we wanted to, but  Stanzi won't hear of it. She wants  to do everything herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your financial situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It couldn't be better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? It's wonderful.   Really, it's - it's marvelous! People  love me here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say you're in debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Who says that? Now that's a  malicious lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many pupils do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pupils?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's not important. I  mean, I don't want pupils. They get  in the way. I've got to have time  for composition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Composition doesn't pay. You know  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up some pages of manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let's not talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have secrets from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too dangerous, Papa. But they're  going to love it. Ah, there she is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze comes into the room. She is wearing a dressing  gown and has made a perfunctory attempt to tidy her hair. We see that she is clearly pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Stanzi - look at her! Isn't she  beautiful? Come on now, confess,  Papa. Could you want a prettier girl  for a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, Wolfi. I look dreadful.   Welcome to our house, Herr Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not Herr Mozart. Call him Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see that you're expecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When, may I ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In three months! Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that marvelous? We're delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you mention it in your  letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I? I thought I did. I'm sure  I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a little giggle of embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I offer you some tea, Herr Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea? Who wants tea? Let's go out!   This calls for a feast. You don't  want tea, Papa. Let's go dancing.   Papa loves parties, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? How can you be so boring?   Tea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi, I think your father's tired.   I'll cook us something here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. That'll be fine. Don't  spend any money on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Oh, come, Papa! What better  way could I spend it than on you? My  kissable, missable, suddenly visible  Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jaunty tune of Ich Mochte Wohl Der Kaiser sein (K.539 sounds through all the following. This is an alternate so from Il Seraglio: a very extroverted tune for baritone an orchestra and a prominent part for bass drum. The vocal p should be arranged for trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart and Constanze with Leopold between them. We see co shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a shop where one can buy costumes for masquerades It is filled with extravagant costumes of various kinds. Wolfgang is wearing a costume, a mask pushed up on his  forehead; Constanze is wearing a little white velvet mask Amidst the merriment, Leopold is helped by two assistants put on a dark grey cloak and a dark grey tricorne hat, to which is attached a full mask of dark grey. Its mouth is into a fixed upward smile. He turns and looks at his son through this mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the full whirl of a Masquerade Ball. Couples ar dancing around dressed in fantastic costumes. The music o Ich Mochte Wohl Der Kaiser sein increases in volume and  persists. We see the musicians thumping it out on a balus above the dancers. A steer is being roasted. Through the  bobbing crowd we see a group, headed by the figure of Bac this is Schikaneder in a Greek costume, wearing vine leav in his hair. He is accompanied by his usual trio of actre and three other men. Constanze as Columbine and Mozart as Harlequin are pulling Leopold by the hand of his dark clo and smiling mask. This whole group threads its way across the crowded room and disappears through a door. As they g they are watched by Salieri, standing alone in a corner,  wearing ordinary evening clothes. He turns away hastily t avoid being seen by them. As soon as they disappear into the far room, Salieri goes quickly to a lady in the corner who is giving guests domi masks off a tray. He quickly takes a small black mask and puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fantastic room designed as a rocky grotto, lit by candl A forte-piano to one side is being played by Schikaneder: the music of Ich Mochte Wohl Der Kaiser sein cross-fades another tune.  This is Vivat Bacchus from Il Seraglio whi Schikaneder, dressed as Bacchus, is humming as he plays. music is actually accompanying a game of Forfeits, which begun. Five couples (the group we have just seen) are dan in the middle of a ring made by nine chairs. When the mus stops they will each have to find a chair, and the one wh fails must pay a forfeit. Constanze is dancing with Leopold; Mozart is dancing with one of the actresses; the two other actresses are dancing with two other gentlemen; and two children dance together a little boy and a little girl. The scene is watched by a circle of bystanders; among them - from the doorway - is  Salieri. Schikaneder stops playing. Immediately the couples scramb for the chairs. Leopold and Constanze meet on the same ch bumping and pushing at each other to get sole possession it. To the amusement of the people around, the chair over balances and they both end up on the floor. Constanze  immediately gets up again, sets the chair on its feet, an tries to pretend she was sitting in it all the time. But  Schikaneder calls out from the forte-piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no! You both lost. You both lost.  You both have to forfeit. And the  penalty is you must exchange your  wigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are delighted by the idea of this penalty. The chi jump up and down with excitement. The three actresses  immediately surround Leopold, reaching for his hat and ma and wig, whilst he tries to hold on to them. Mozart takes off Constanze's wig - an absurd affair with side-curls.  Constanze laughingly surrenders it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please! This is ridiculous! No,  please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite his protests an actress takes off his hat, to whi the smiling mask is attached, to reveal his outraged face showing a very different expression underneath. Another  actress snatches off his wig to reveal very sparse hair o the old man's head. The third actress takes Constanze's w from Mozart and attempts to put it on his father's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to him) This is just a game, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze echoes him with a touch of malice in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just a game, Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughingly, the bystanders take it up, especially the  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just a game, Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Leopold glares furiously about him, the actress succee in getting Constanze's wig firmly onto his head. Everybod bursts into applause. Delightedly, Constanze puts on Leop wig, hat and mask: from the waist up she now looks like a weird parody of Leopold in the smiling grey mask, and he  looks like a weird parody of her in the silly feminine wi Schikaneder starts to play again, and the couples start t dance. Leopold angrily takes off Constanze's wig and leav the circle; his partner, Constanze, is left alone. Seeing this, Mozart leaves his partner and catches his father  entreatingly by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, Papa, please! Don't spoil the  fun. Come on. Here, take mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off his own wig and puts it on Leopold's uncover head. The effect, if not as ridiculous, is still somewhat bizarre, since Wolfgang favours fairly elaborate wigs. He takes Constanze's wig from his father. As this happens, t music stops again. Mozart gently pushes his father down o a nearby chair; the others scramble for the other chairs; and he is left as the Odd Man Out. He giggles. Schikanede calls out to Leopold from the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart, why don't you name your  son's penalty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Papa, name it. Name it. I'll do  anything you say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to come back with me to  Salzburg, my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say? What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, the rule is you can only give  penalties that can be performed in  the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of this game. Please play  without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my penalty. I've got to have a  penalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the bystanders are watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a good one. I've got the  perfect one for you. Come over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart runs over to the forte-piano, and Schikaneder  surrenders his place at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I want you to play our tune -  sitting backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's really too easy. Any child  can do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amused sounds of disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a fugue in the manner of Sebastian  Bach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renewed applause at this wicked extra penalty. Mozart smi at Schikaneder - it is the sort of challenge he loves. He defiantly puts on Constanze's wig and seats himself with back to the keyboard. Before the astonished eyes of the  company he proceeds to execute this absurdly difficult ta His right hand plays the bass part, his left hand the tre and with this added difficulty he improvises a brilliant  fugue on the subject of the tune to which they have been  dancing. Attracted by this astonishing feat, the players draw near to the instrument. So does Salieri, cautiously, with some the bystanders. Constanze watches him approach. Only Leop sits by himself, sulking. The fugue ends amidst terrific clapping. The guests call to Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another! Do another! Someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a name. Who shall I do?   Give me a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gluck! Haydn! Frederic Handel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri! Do Salieri!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMASH CUT: Salieri's masked face whips around and looks a her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's hard. That's very hard.  For Salieri one has to face the right  way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giggling, he turns around and sits at the keyboard. Then, watched by a highly amused group, he begins a wicked paro He furrows his brow in mock concentration and closes his  eyes. Then he begins to play the tune to which they dance in the most obvious way imaginable, relying heavily on a  totally and offensively unimaginative bass of tonic and  dominant, endlessly repeated. The music is the very essen of banality. The bystanders rock with laughter. Mozart st to giggle wildly. Through this excruciating scene, Salier stares at Constanze, who suddenly turns her head and look challengingly back at him. Mozart's parody reaches its coarse climax with him adding fart noise instead of notes to end cadences. He builds th up, urged on in his clowning by everyone else, until sudd he stops and cries out. The laughter cuts off. Mozart sta up, clutching his behind as if he has made a mess in his  breeches. The momentary hush of alarm is followed by a ho of laughter. CU, Salieri staring in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, The old man is shaking at the very recollection of hi humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Mock me. Laugh, laugh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A repetition of the shot of Mozart at the forte-piano, we Constanze's wig and emitting a shrill giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri sits at his desk. He holds in his hand the small  black party mask and stares in hatred at the place on the wall where the crucifix used to hang. Faintly we see the  mark of the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was not Mozart laughing, Father.   That was God. That was God! God  laughing at me through that obscene  giggle. Go on, Signore. Laugh. Rub  my nose in it. Show my mediocrity  for all to see. You wait! I will  laugh at You! Before I leave this  earth, I will laugh at You! Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is littered with manuscripts. In the middle stands a  billiard table. The beautiful closing ensemble from Act I of Figaro: Ah, Tutti contenti! Saremo cosi plays in the  background. Standing at the billiard table, Mozart is dre hearing the music and playing shots on the table. From time to time he drifts over to a piece of manuscript paper and jots down notes. He is very much in his own wor of composition and the billiard balls are an aid to creat Presently, however, we hear a knocking at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outside the door) Wolfi! Wolfgang!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a young girl to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ask her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't talk to me. She says she  has to speak to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart comes out. Framed in the doorway from outside stan Lorl, the maid we noticed in Salieri's house. From his be Leopold peeps out to watch. Mozart goes to the girl. Cons follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Herr Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Lorl, sir. I'm a  maidservant. I was asked to come  here and offer my services to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be paid for by a great admirer  or yours who wishes to remain anon -  anonymous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What admirer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you that, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying that someone is paying  you to be our maid and doesn't want  us to know who he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I can live in or out just as  you wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart turns to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, is this your idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man emerges from his bedroom. His son looks at hi delightedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you playing a trick on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw this girl in my life. (to Lorl) Is this a kind of joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, sir. And I was told to  wait for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young woman, this won't do at all.   My son can't possibly accept such an  offer, no matter how generous, unless  he knows who is behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I really can't tell you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is ridiculous? Wolfi has many  admirers in Vienna. They love him  here. People send us gifts all the  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't take her without  reference. It's unheard of!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is none of your business. (to Lorl) Whoever sent you is going to pay,  no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now we are going to let a perfect  stranger into the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze looks furiously at him, then at Lorl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is we? Who is letting who? (to Lorl) Could you please wait outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorl goes outside and closes the door. Constanze turns on Leopold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, old man, you stay out of this.   We spend a fortune on you, more than  we can possibly afford, and all you  do is criticize, morning to night.  And then you think you can -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanzi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's right he should hear. I'm  sick to death of it. We can't do  anything right for you, can we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. You won't have to do  anything for me ever again. I'm  leaving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'm not staying here to  be a burden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one calls you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does. She says I sleep all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so you do! The only time you  come out is to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you expect? Who wants to  walk out into a mess like this every  day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now I'm a bad housekeeper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are! The place is a pigsty  all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mozart) Do you hear him? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explosively she opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lorl) When can you start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! Come in. You'll start with  that room there. (indicating Leopold's  room) It's filthy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads the maid into Leopold's room. Mozart steals bac into his workroom and gently closes the door. Leopold is  left alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry! I'm sorry I spoke!   I'm just a provincial from Salzburg.   What do I know about smart Vienna?   Parties all night, every night.  Dancing and drinking like idiot  children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart stands trying to blot out the noise of his father' shouting from the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner at eight! Dinner at ten! Dinner  when anyone feels like it! If anyone  feels like it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ensemble of Ah, Tutti contenti! Saremo cosi from Act of Figaro resumes, coming to his aid and rising to greet listener with its serene harmonies. Relieved, Mozart lang picks up his cue and plays a shot on the billiard table: is sucked back into his own world of sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music fades. We see Lorl, dressed in a walking cloak, sitting before a desk, talking to someone confidentially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're out every night, sir. Till  all hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand comes into frame offering a plate of sugared biscu On its finger we see the gold signet ring belonging to  Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking one) Oh, thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do any pupils come to the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I've seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how does he pay for all this?   Does he work at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, sir, all day long. He never  leaves the house until evening. He  just sits there, writing and writing.   He doesn't even eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What is it he's writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't know that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. You're a good girl.   You're very kind to do this. Next  time you're sure they'll be out of  the house, let me know, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused, the girl hesitates. He hands her a pile of coin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She accepts them, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final movement of Mozart's Piano Concerto in E-flat ( 482) begins. To its lively music, the door of the house b open and a grand forte-piano augmented with a pedal is ca out of it by six men, who run off with it down the street Following them immediately appear Wolfgang, Constanze and Leopold, all three dressed for an occasion. They climb in a waiting carriage which drives off after the forte-piano As soon as it goes, Lorl appears in the doorway, peering  slyly around to see that they are out of sight. Then she  shuts the door and hurries off in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outdoor concert is being given. Mozart is actually pla the final movement of his E-flat concerto with an orchest Listening to him is a sizable audience, including the Emp flanked by Strack and Von Swieten. The crowd is in a happy and appreciative mood: it is a  delightful open-air scene. We hear the gayest and most co passage. Leopold and Constanze listen to Mozart, who play his own work brilliantly. We stay with this scene for a l while and then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carriage clopping through the streets. Lorl is sitting on the box beside the driver. Inside the vehicle, we glim the figure of Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear more of the concerto. Perhaps the slow interlude the last movement of K. 482. Mozart is conducting and pla in a reflective mood. Abruptly we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorl is opening the door admitting Salieri. They go in. T door shuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is considerably tidier as a result of Lorl's  ministrations. Salieri stands looking about him with  tremendous curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've found out about the  money, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens a drawer in a sideboard. Inside we see one gold snuff box: it is the one we saw Mozart being presented wi as a child in the Vatican.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kept seven snuff boxes in here.   I could swear they were all gold.  And now look there's only one left.  And inside, sir, look - I counted  them - tickets from the pawnshop.  Six of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri turns to look around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does he work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In there, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points across the room to the workroom. Salieri cross and goes in alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri enters the private quarters of Amadeus. He is  immensely excited. He moves slowly into the 'holy of holi picking up objects with great reverence - a billiard ball discarded wig; a sock; a buckle - then objects more impor to him. Standing at Mozart's desk, strewn with manuscript he picks up Mozart's pen and strokes the feather. He touc the inkstand. He lays a finger on the candlestick with it half-expired candle. He touches each object as if it were the memento of a beloved. He is in awe. Finally his eye f on the sheets of music themselves. Stealthily he picks th up. CU, The pages. We see words set to music. Against each line of notes is name of a character: Contessa, Susanna, Cherubino. Then  another page - the title page - written in Mozart's hand. Le Nozze di Figaro Comedia per musica tratta dal Francese quattro atti. CU, The word Figaro. CU, Salieri. He stares amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is playing the cadenza and coda of Piano Concerto 482). He completes the work with a flourish. There is lou applause. The Emperor rises and all follow suit. Mozart c down to be greeted by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo, Mozart. Most charming. Yes,  indeed. Clever man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, Mozart. Really quite fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees his wife and father standing by in the crowd. Leo is signaling insistently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, may I ask you to do me the  greatest favour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I introduce my father? He is on  a short visit here and returning  very soon to Salzburg. He would so  much like to kiss your hand. It would  make his whole stay so memorable for  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! By all means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leopold comes forward eagerly and fawningly kisses the ro hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze curtsies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. (to Leopold) We have met before, Herr Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Your Majesty. Twenty  years ago. No, twenty-two! twenty- three! And I remember word for word  what you said to me. You said - you  said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He searches his memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Yes, 'bravo,' of course 'bravo'!   Everybody always says 'bravo' when  Wolfi plays. Like the King of England.   When we played for the King of  England, he got up at the end and  said, 'Bravo! Bravo! Bravo!' three  times. Three bravo's. And the Pope  four! Four bravo's from the Holy  Father, and one 'bellissimo.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the courtiers around are looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush! I'm talking to His Majesty.  Your Majesty, I wish to express only  one thing - that you who are the  Father of us all, could teach our  children the gratitude they owe to  fathers. It is not for nothing that  the Fifth Commandment tells us:  'Honour your Father and Mother, that  your days may be long upon the earth.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. Well. There it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Director sits at his table with Salieri and Bonno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just learned something that  might be of interest to you, Herr  Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is writing a new opera. An  Italian opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Italian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's not all. He has chosen  for his subject, Figaro. The Marriage  of Figaro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean that play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's setting that play to music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this Marriage of Figaro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a French play, Kapellmeister.   It has been banned by the Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses himself, wide-eyed with alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know we banned this play, but  frankly I can't remember why. Can  you refresh my memory, Herr Director?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the same reason, Herr Chamberlain,  that it was banned in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, yes. And that was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the play makes a hero out of a  valet. He outwits his noble master  and exposes him as a lecher. Do you  see the implications? This would be,  in a grander situation, as if a  Chamberlain were to expose an Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Emperor stands in the middle of the room in close  conversation with Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Von Swiet and Bonno. Salieri is not present. A door opens and a lac announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all turn. Mozart approaches, rather apprehensively, kisses Joseph's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, gentlemen, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all sit, save Mozart. The room suddenly looks like a tribunal. Joseph is in a serious mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart, are you aware I have declared  the French play of Figaro unsuitable  for our theatre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet we hear you are making an opera  from it. Is this true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you this, Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not your place to ask questions.   Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I admit it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you tell me why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Majesty, it is only a comedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you think, Mozart, is scarcely  the point. It is what His Majesty  thinks that counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Your Majesty -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning him to be  silent) Mozart, I am a tolerant man. I do  not censor things lightly. When I  do, I have good reason. Figaro is a  bad play. It stirs up hatred between  the classes. In France it has caused  nothing but bitterness. My own dear  sister Antoinette writes me that she  is beginning to be frightened of her  own people. I do not wish to see the  same fears starting here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire, I swear to Your Majesty, there's  nothing like that in the story. I  have taken out everything that could  give offense. I hate politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you are rather innocent, my  friend. In these dangerous times I  cannot afford to provoke our nobles  or our people simply over a theatre  piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others look at their king solemnly, all save Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Majesty, this is just a frolic.   It's a piece about love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, love again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's new, it's entirely new.  It's so new, people will go mad for  it. For example, I have a scene in  the second act - it starts as a duet,  just a man and wife quarreling.  Suddenly the wife's scheming little  maid comes in unexpectedly - a very  funny situation. Duet turns into  trio. Then the husband's equally  screaming valet comes in. Trio turns  into quartet. Then a stupid old  gardener - quartet becomes quintet,  and so on.  On and on, sextet, septet,  octet! How long do you think I can  sustain that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess! Guess, Majesty. Imagine the  longest time such a thing could last,  then double it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, six or seven minutes! maybe  eight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty, sire! How about twenty?   Twenty minutes of continuous music.   No recitatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
