dialogues.text: (ignoring him) Sire, only opera can do this. In a  play, if more than one person speaks  at the same time, it's just noise.   No one can understand a word. But  with music, with music you can have  twenty individuals all talking at  once, and it's not noise - it's a  perfect harmony. Isn't that marvelous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart, music is not the issue here.  No one doubts your talent. It is  your judgment of literature that's  in question. Even with the politics  taken out, this thing would still  remain a vulgar farce. Why waste  your spirit on such rubbish?  Surely  you can choose more elevated themes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevated? What does that mean?  Elevated! The only thing a man should  elevate is - oh, excuse me. I'm sorry.  I'm stupid. But I am fed up to the  teeth with elevated things! Old dead  legends! How can we go on forever  writing about gods and legends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aroused) Because they do. They go on forever -  at least what they represent. The  eternal in us, not the ephemeral.  Opera is here to ennoble us. You and  me, just as much as His Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bello! Bello, Barone. Veramente.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, bello, bello, bello! Come on  now, be honest. Wouldn't you all  rather listen to your hairdressers  than Hercules? Or Horatius? Or  Orpheus? All those old bores! people  so lofty they sound as if they shit  marble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Govern your tongue, sir! How dare  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. All look at the Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Majesty. I'm a vulgar  man. But I assure you, my music is  not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are passionate, Mozart! But you  do not persuade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire, the whole opera is finished.  Do you know how much work went into  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Majesty has been more than  patient, Signore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I persuade you if you won't  let me show it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will do, Herr Mozart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me tell you how it begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I just do that, Majesty? Show  you how it begins? Just that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight pause. Then Joseph nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart falls on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! There's a servant, down on his  knees. Do you know why? Not from any  oppression. No, he's simply measuring  a space. Do you know what for? His  bed. His wedding bed to see if it  will fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart sits on stage at a harpsichord rehearsing the sing taking the parts of Figaro and Susanna in the opening bar of the first act of The Marriage of Figaro. We watch Figa measuring the space for his bed on the floor, singing and Susanna looking on, trying on the Countess' hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno are sitting with Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mozart is already rehearsing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Emperor has given him permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si, si! Veramente.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, so be it. In that  case I think we should help Mozart  all we can and do our best to protect  him against the Emperor's anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What anger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the ballet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballet? What ballet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me - didn't His Majesty  specifically forbid ballet in his  opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, absolutely. Is there a ballet  in Figaro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, in the third act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a full orchestral rehearsal. Mozart is conducting f the harpsichord with his hands; he does not use a baton. The singers are all in practice clothes, not costumes. We are in the Act III and we hear the recitativo exchange just before the march begins. Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno watching chairs. Suddenly the march starts. Peasants and friends start to  dance in and at the same moment, Orsini-Rosenberg gets up and comes down to Mozart. He is accompanied by an anxious Bonno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart! Herr Mozart, may I have a  word with you please. Right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Herr Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signals to the cast to break off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company disperses, curious. The musicians look at Ors Rosenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not know that His Majesty  has expressly forbidden ballet in  his operas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but this is not a ballet. This  is a dance at Figaro's wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. A dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But surely the Emperor didn't mean  to prohibit dancing when it's part  of the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dangerous for you to interpret  His Majesty's edicts. Give me your  score, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart hands him the score from which he is conducting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips out a page. Bonno watches in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips out three more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Herr Director?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking out what you should never  have put in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes on tearing the pages determinedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A servant opens the door to announce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart brushes past him straight towards Salieri, who ris to greet him. The little man is near hysterics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Please. I've no one else to  turn to. Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfgang, what is it? Sta calmo, per  favore. What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's unbelievable! The Director has  actually ripped out a huge section  of my music. Pages of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. They say I've got to  re-write the opera, but it's perfect  as it is. I can't rewrite what's  perfect. Can't you talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why bother with Orsini-Rosenberg?   He's obviously no friend of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I could kill him! I mean really  kill him. I actually threw the entire  opera on the fire, he made me so  angry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You burned the score?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no! My wife took it out in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How fortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not fair that a man like that  has power over our work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there are those who have power  over him. I think I'll take this up  with the Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Excellency, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all my heart, Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you! Oh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses Salieri's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (withdrawing it;  imitating the Emperor) No, no, no, Herr Mozart, please.   It's not a holy relic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart giggles with relief and gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I don't need to tell you I  said nothing whatever to the Emperor.   I went to the theatre ready to tell  Mozart that His Majesty had flown  into a rage when I mentioned the  ballet, when suddenly, to my  astonishment, in the middle of the  third act, the Emperor - who never  attended rehearsals - suddenly  appeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background the same recitativo before the March. T Emperor steals in surreptitiously with Von Strack, his fi to his lips. He motions everyone not to rise, and slips i a chair behind Salieri, Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno. The three conspirators look at each other wide-eyed. The recitativo summons up the march, but instead there is silence. Mozart lays down his baton. The musicians lay do their instruments. The celebrants of Figaro's wedding com in with a few pitiful dance steps, in procession, only to come presently to a halt, lacking their music. The singer try to go on singing, but they have no cues from their  conductor or from the accompaniment. Everyone on stage lo lost, though they attempt to go on with the story for a w Consternation grows on the faces of the conspirators. Moz glances back at the group seated in the theatre.  Finally the Emperor speaks, in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? I don't understand.   Is it modern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, the Herr Director, he has  removed a balleto that would have  occurred at this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is your regulation, Sire. No ballet  in your opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart strains to hear what they are saying but cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like this, Salieri?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not a question of liking, Your  Majesty. Your own law decrees it,  I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do look at them. The spectacle on stage has now ground a complete halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no! This is nonsense. Let me  hear the scene with the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Sire -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblige me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orsini-Rosenberg acknowledges his defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orsini-Rosenberg rises and goes down to where Mozart sits anxiously with the musicians, watching his approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we see the scene with the music  back, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, certainly. Certainly, Herr  Director!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back deliriously at Salieri, trying to indicate gratitude. Salieri acknowledges with a slight and subtle  nod. Orsini-Rosenberg returns to his king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, we're going  from where we stopped. The Count:  Anches so. Right away, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The singers scatter offstage to begin the scene again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Orsini-Rosenberg) What I hoped by that edict, Director,  was simply to prevent hours of dancing  like in French opera. There it is  endless, as you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite so, Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT BACK TO Mozart at the forte-piano, raising his hands. The musicians raise their bows. With a flourish the happy composer begins a reprise of the scene which had been cut out. The music of the march begins faintly; the celebrant of Figaro's wedding start to enter as the Count and the  Countess sit in their chairs. In the theatre we see increasing pleasure on the Emperor' face, sullenness and defeat on the courtiers'. Then, sudd without interruption, on a crescendo repeat of the march,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theatre is brilliantly lit for the first public  performance of Figaro. Everybody is there: the Emperor, V Strack, Bonno Orsini-Rosenberg, Von Swieten, even Madame  Weber and her daughters in a box. The musicians all wear  imperial livery; the actors on stage are now in costume. Mozart, conducting, wears his Order of the Golden Spur. T company wheels in and around to the music of the restored march, which reaches a triumphant climax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vogler) So Figaro was produced in spite of  me. And in spite of me, a wonder was  revealed. One of the true wonders of  art. The restored third act was bold  and brilliant. The fourth was a  miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The descending scale of strings in the final ensemble (Ah Tutti contenti. Saremo cosi) fades in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the tableau on stage with the Count kneeling to th Countess. All are singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a woman disguised in her maid's  clothes hear her husband speak the  first tender words he has offered  her in years, only because he thinks  she is someone else. I heard the  music of true forgiveness filling  the theatre, conferring on all who  sat there a perfect absolution. God  was singing through this little man  to all the world - unstoppable -  making my defeat more bitter with  each passing bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Salieri in his box, tears on his cheeks. He watches t ensemble and we listen to it for a long moment. Finally i fades, but continues underneath the following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then suddenly - a miracle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ensemble reaches its climax, and fades away to the ve quiet, slow chords immediately preceding the boisterous f chord. Salieri becomes aware that some of the audience ar asleep and many mare are apathetic. In the near silence w see the Emperor yawn behind his hand. Those nearby look a him. Orsini-Rosenberg smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, did you know what that meant?   With that yawn I saw my defeat turn  into a victory. And Mozart was lucky  the Emperor only yawned once. Three  yawns and the opera would fail the  same night; two yawns, within a week  at most. With one yawn the composer  could still get -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is pacing up and down. Salieri is listening  sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine performances! Nine! That's all  it's had - and withdrawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know; it's outrageous. Still, if  the public doesn't like one's work  one has to accept the fact gracefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what is it they don't like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can speak for the Emperor.  You made too many demands on the  royal ear. The poor man can't  concentrate for more than an hour  and you gave him four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think of it yourself?   Did you like it at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's marvelous. Truly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the best opera yet written. I  know it! Why didn't they come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you overestimate our dear  Viennese, my friend. Do you know you  didn't even give them a good bang at  the end of songs so they knew when  to clap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. Perhaps you should  give me some lessons in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fuming) I wouldn't presume. All the same, if  it wouldn't be imposing, I would  like you to see my new piece. It  would be a tremendous honour for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, the honour would be all mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing) Grazie, mio caro, Wolfgang!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grazie, a lei, Signor Antonio!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows too, giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A performance of Salieri's grand opera, Axur: King of Orm Deafening applause from a crowded house. We see the recep of the aria which we saw Cavalieri singing on the stage n the start of the film. Cavalieri, in a mythological Persi costume, is bowing to the rapturous throng; below her is  Salieri. We see the Emperor, Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg Bonno and Von Swieten, all applauding. We hear great crie of 'Salieri! Salieri!' and 'Bravo!' and 'Brava!' CU, Salieri looking at the crowd with immense pleasure.   Then suddenly at: CU, Mozart standing in a box and clapping wildly. Behind  him, seated, are Schikaneder and the three girls we saw b in Mozart's apartment. CU, Salieri staring fixedly at Mozart, then Mozart still  clapping, apparently with tremendous enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was this? I never saw him excited  before by any music but his own.  Could he mean it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vogler) Would he actually tell me my music  had moved him? Was I really going to  hear that from his own lips? I found  myself actually hurrying the tempo  of the finale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri conducting the last scene from Axur: King of Ormu On stage we see a big scene of acclamation: the hero and  heroine of the opera accepting the crown amidst the rejoi of the people. The decor and costumes are mythological  Persian. The music is utterly conventional and totally  uninventive. CU, Mozart watching this in his box, with Schikaneder and the three actresses. He passes an open bottle of wine to  them. He is evidently a little drunk, but keeps a poker f The act comes to an end. Great applause in which Mozart j in, standing and shouting 'Bravo! Bravo!' Then he leaves box with Schikaneder and the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Schikaneder) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock moved) Sublime! Utterly sublime!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kind of music should be  punishable by death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schikaneder laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of people rings Salieri at a respectful distance. The Emperor is holding out the Civilian Medal and Chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe that is the best opera yet  written, my friends. Salieri, you  are the brightest star in the musical  firmament. You do honour to Vienna  and to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri bows his head. Joseph places the chain around his neck. The crowd claps. Salieri makes to kiss his hand, bu Joseph restrains him, and passes on. Cavalieri, smiling  adoringly, gives him a deep curtsey, and he raises her up The crowd all flock to Salieri with cries and words of  approval. All want to shake his hand. They tug and pat hi But he has eyes for only one man - he looks about him,  searching for him and then finds him. Mozart stands there Eagerly Salieri moves to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart. It was good of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did my work please you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could it not, Excellency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never knew that music like that  was possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You flatter me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no! One hears such sounds and  what can one say, but - Salieri!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explosive laughter as Mozart and Schikaneder enter the  apartment, very pleased with themselves and accompanied b the three actresses. The front door opens, very gingerly. Mozart, still rather drunk, sticks his head into the room anxious not to make a noise. He sees the strangers and br into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Everybody's here! We've got  guests. Good. I've brought some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door wide to admit Schikaneder and the girls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have a little party. Come in.  Come in. You know Herr Schikaneder? (to a girl) This is! a very nice girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) Wolfi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These gentlemen are from Salzburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salzburg.  We were just talking about  Salzburg. (to the two men,  jubilantly) If you've come from my friend the  Fartsbishop, you've arrived at just  the right moment. Because I've got  good news for him. I'm done with  Vienna. It's over, finished, done  with! Done with! Done with!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi! Your father is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first loud chord of the Statue scene from Don Giovann sounds. Mozart stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second chord sounds. On stage we see the huge figure the Commendatore in robes and helmet, extending his arms pointing in accusation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second chord sounds. On stage we see a huge nailed fist crash through the wall a painted dining room set. The giant armoured statue of t COMMENDATORE enters pointing his finger in accusation at Giovanni who sits at the supper table, staring - his serv Leporello quaking with fear under the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Don Giovanni!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure advances on the libertine. We see Mozart  conducting, pale and deeply involved. Music fades down a  little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So rose the dreadful ghost in his  next and blackest opera. There on  the stage stood the figure of a dead  commander calling out 'Repent!  Repent!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells. We see Salieri standing alone in the ba of a box, unseen, in semi-darkness. We also see that the  theatre is only half full. Music fades down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I knew - only I understood -  that the horrifying apparition was  Leopold, raised from the dead.  Wolfgang had actually summoned up  his own father to accuse his son  before all the world. It was  terrifying and wonderful to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music swells up again. We watch the scene on stage as the Commendatore addresses Giovanni. Then back to Salieri in box. Music down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now a madness began in me. The madness  of a man splitting in half. Through  my influence I saw to it Don Giovanni  was played only five times in Vienna.   But in secret I went to every one of  those five - all alone - unable to  help myself, worshipping sound I  alone seemed to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And hour after hour, as I stood there,  understanding even more clearly how  that bitter old man was still  possessing his poor son from beyond  the grave, I began to see a way - a  terrible way - I could finally triumph  over God, my torturer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music swells. On stage Don Giovanni is seized and gripped the Statue's icy hand. Flames burst from obviously artifi rocks. Demons appear and drag the libertine down to Hell. The scene ends. CU, Salieri, staring wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see huge and attractive posters and billboards adverti Schikaneder's troupe. The camera concentrates on the one  which reads as follows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impresario de luxe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Celebrated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Evening of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music!  Mirth!  Magic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who personally will appear in every scene!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noise; smoke; the audience is sitting at tables for an ev of vaudeville. Mozart, Constanze and their son Karl, now  about two years old, and sitting on his mother's lap, are watching a parody scene by Schikaneder's troupe. They are rowdy, bawdy and silly, incorporating motifs, situations tunes from Mozart's operas which we have seen and heard.  Before them on the table are bottles of wine and beer, pl of sausages, etc.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARODY
dialogues.text: On stage we see a set which parodies the dining room in D Giovanni's palace, shown before. Schikaneder as Don Giovanni is dancing with the three  actresses to the minuet from Don Giovanni (end of Act I), played by a quartet of tipsy musicians. Leporello is hand around wine on a tray. Suddenly there is a tremendous knocking from outside. The music slithers to a stop. All look at each other in panic Leporello drops his tray with a crash. All go quiet. One  more knock is heard. Then all musicians, actresses, Don  Giovanni and Leporello make a dash to hide under the tabl which is far too small to accommodate them all. The table rocks. Schikaneder is pushed out. He is terrified. He sha elaborately. Three more knocks are heard; louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C-c-c-come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the pit a chromatic scale from the Overture to Don Gio turns into a anticipatory vamp. This grows more and more  menacing until the whole flat representing the wall at th back falls down. An absurd pantomime horse gallops in. It has a ridiculous expression, and is manned by four men inside. Standing  precariously on its back is a dwarf, wearing a miniature  version of the armour and helmet worn by the Commendatore He sings in a high, nasal voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Don Giovannnnnnnnnni!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to keep his balance as he trots in, but fails. H falls off onto the stage. He beats at the horse, trying t get back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down! Down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bewildered, the horse looks about him, but cannot see his small rider who is below his level of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here! I'm here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse, amidst laughter from the audience, fails to lo him. Exasperated, the dwarf signals to someone in the win A tall man strides out carrying a see-saw; on his shoulde stands another man. The dwarf stands on the lowered end of the see-saw. There a drum roll and the man above jumps down onto the raised and the Commendatore is abruptly catapulted back onto the horse, only backwards so that he is facing away from Don  Giovanni. The two men bow to the applauding audience, and retire off-stage. The Commendatore tries to extend his arms in the proper  menacing attitude, and at the same time turn around to fa Don Giovanni. This he finds difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Don Giovannnnnnnni!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the devil are you? What do you  want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) I've come to dinnnnnner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner? How dare you? I am a nobleman.  I only dine with people of my own  height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you drunk? You invited me. And  my horse. Here he is. Ottavio!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse takes a bow. The dwarf almost falls off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Whoa! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three girls rush to his aid and reach him just in tim They sing in the manner of the Tree Ladies later to be pu into The Magic Flute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running and singing) Be careful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running and singing) Be careful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running and singing) Be careful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (close harmony) Hold tight now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grab him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Leave me alone! Stop it! I'm a famous  horseman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm a famous horse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the ladies a radiant smile. The three ladies sin as before, in close harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) He's adorable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Adorable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Adorable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orchestral chord. The three ladies turn to Ottavio and sing to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing together) Give me your hoof, my darling, And  I'll give you my heart! Take me to  your stable, And never more we'll  part!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing: four male  voices) I'm shy and very bashful. I don't  know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing together) Don't hesitate a second. Just answer  yes and neigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ottavio neighs loudly, and runs at the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) Stop it. What are you doing? Remember  who you are! You're a horse and they  are whores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boos from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) This is ridiculous. I won't have any  of it. You're turning my house into  a circus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trapeze sails in from above. On it stands a grand sopra wearing an elaborate Turkish costume, like a parody of  Cavalieri's in Il Seraglio. She comes in singing a mad  coloratura scale in the manner of Martern aller Arten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) Shut up. Women, women, women! I'm  sick to death of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He marches off stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing dramatically) Dash me! Bash me! Lash me! Flay me!   Slay me! At last I will be freed by  death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swinging and singing) Kill me! Kill me! Kill me! Kill me!  At last I shall be freed by death.  At last I shall be freed by dea -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commendatore pulls out his sword, reaches up and thru her through with it. The soprano collapses on the bar of trapeze. The audience applauds. At the same moment eight  dwarves march in bearing a huge cauldron of steaming wate They sing as they march to the sound of the march that wa cut from Act III of Figaro. They are dressed as miniature copies of the chorus in that scene except that they are  wearing cooks' hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) We're going to make a soprano stew!  We're going to make a soprano stew!  And when you make a soprano stew!  Any stupid soprano will do! Any stew- stew-stew-stew-stew! Any stewpid  soprano will do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They set the giant pot down in the middle of the stage. T trapeze with the dead soprano is still swinging above the stage. We hear the chromatic scale from the Don Giovanni overtur again, repeated and repeated, only now fast and tremoland To this exciting vamp Schikaneder suddenly rides in on a  real horse, waving a real sword. With this he cuts the st of the trapeze, and the soprano falls into the pot. A  tremendous splash of water. Schikaneder rides out. More  applause. All the dwarves produce long wooden cooking spoons and cl up the sides of the pot. The three girls produce labeled  bottles from under their skirts. The first is SALT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Behold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Behold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sneezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Behold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hiccups. They throw them into the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking to the  dwarves) How long does it take to cook a  soprano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all together) Five hours, five minutes, five  seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) I can't wait that long. I'm starving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking; four voices) So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schikaneder marches in as Figaro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to the tune  of Non piu ante) In the pot, I have got a good dinner.  Not a sausage or stew, but a singer.  Not a sausage or stew but a singer.  Is the treat that I'll eat for my  meat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shut up. I'm sick to death of  that tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU,  Mozart laughing delightedly with the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing again to the  horse) Give me your hoof, my darling, and  I'll give you my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. I'm sick of that one too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the dwarves climb up the rim of the pot. As they clim they all hum together the opening of Eine Kleine Nachtmus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that one, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soprano rises, dripping with water in the middle of t pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Oil me! Broil me! Boil me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the dwarves beat her back down into the pot with thei long wooden spoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from inside the pot) Soil me! Foil me! Spoil me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't eat her. Sopranos give me  hiccups. I want some hay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to Schikaneder) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to Schikaneder) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to Schikaneder) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to La oi  daram) Give him some hay, my darling, and  I'll give you my heart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leporello! We want some hay -  prestissimo! Leporello - where are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is raised in the air by Leporello sitting under on a bale of hay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to horse) Behold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to horse) Behold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to horse) Behold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ottavio the horse gives a piercing neigh and runs down to the hay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding on) Hey! Hey! Watch out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vamp starts again vigorously. The horse's rear-end sw around on a hinge to turn his hind-quarters straight on t the audience. The rest of him stays sideways. His tail sp up in the air to reveal a lace handkerchief modestly hidi his arsehole. Schikaneder offers him a handful of hay. The horse eats i and out the other end comes a long Viennese sausage. The  audience roars with laughter. Another handful of hay and of the other end falls a string of sausages. Then a large pie, crust and all. Then a shower of iced cakes!  Suddenly - silence. Schikaneder produces an egg from his  pocket. Ottavio the horse rears up in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Whoa, Ottavio! Whoa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leporello pries open the horse's mouth. Schikaneder pops egg into it. A breathless pause as a drum roll builds the tension, up and up and up, and then suddenly out of the  horse's rear-end flies a single white dove. Wild applause. It flies into the audience. Immediately all the cast star humming the lyrical finale from Figaro: Tutti Contenti.   More and more doves fly out from the wings and fill the  theatre. Everybody picks up the sausages and cakes and be to eat. The end of the sketch is unexpectedly lyrical and magical, and then, suddenly, the tempo changes and the co strains of Ich Mochte wohl Der Kaiser take over and the w company is dancing, frantically. A general dance as the  curtain falls. It rises immediately. The audience - including Mozart - i delighted. They applaud vigorously. Schikaneder takes a b amongst his troupe. Among much whistling and clapping, he finally jumps off the stage and strides through the audie toward the table where Mozart sits with his family. On st a troupe of bag pipers immediately appears to play an old German tune. Some of the audience joins in singing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how do you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is smiling; he has been amused. Constanze has been less amused and is looking apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful! (indicating his baby  son) He liked the monkey, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, it's all good fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schikaneder sits at the table, and drinks from a bottle o wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he marvelous? He cost me a  bundle, that horse, but he's worth  it. I tell you, if you'd played Don  Giovanni here it would have been a  great success. I'm not joking. These  people aren't fools. You could do  something marvelous for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to try them someday. I'm  not sure I'd be much good at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course you would. You belong here,  my boy, not the snobby Court. You  could do anything you felt like here -  the more fantastic the better! That's  what people want, you know: fantasy.   You do a big production, fill it  with beautiful magic tricks and you'll  be absolutely free to do anything  you want. Of course, you'd have to  put a fire in it, because I've got  the best fire machine in the city  and a big flood - I can do you the  finest water effects you ever saw in  your life. Oh, and a few trick  animals. You'd have to use those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you I picked up a snake in  Dresden last week - twelve foot long  -  folds up to six inches, just like a  paper fan. It's a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. You write a proper part  for me with a couple of catchy songs,  I'll guarantee you'll have a triumph- de-luxe. Mind you, it'll have to be  in German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! What else do you think  they speak here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I love that. I'd want it to  be in German. I haven't done anything  in German since Seraglio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there you are. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much will you pay him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Well. Ah, (to Mozart) I see you've got your manager with  you. Well, Madame, how about half  the receipts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the receipts! Stanzi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about now. How much will  you give him now? Down payment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down payment? Who do you think I am?  The Emperor? Whoops, I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises in haste for his next number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay where you are. You're going to  like this next one. We'll speak again.  Triumph-de-luxe, my boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winks at Mozart and disappears toward the stage. Mozar looks after him, enchanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Half the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? We need money now. Either he  pays now, or you don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Stanzi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't trust this man. And I didn't  like what he did with your opera.   It was common.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Karl) Well, you liked it, didn't you?   Monkey-flunki-punki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the house! You'll never see a  penny. I want it here, in my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dirty) Stanzi-manzi, I'll put it in your  hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! I'll not let you put anything  in my hand until I see some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles like a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogs are barking wickedly. Michael Schlumberg comes in fr his salon. Mozart stands there looking very unwell and  bewildered. He is also drunk, but making a careful attemp to keep his composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart. What a surprise. What  can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my pupil still anxious to learn  the art of music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your pupil is married and living  in Mannheim, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Perhaps your dear wife might  care to profit from my instruction?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Mozart? What's the  matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Since it appears nobody is  eager to hire my services, could you  favour me with a little money instead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a man cannot earn, he must borrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is hardly the way to go  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt, sir. But I am endowed with  talent, and you with money. If I  offer mine, you should offer yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. I'll give it back, I promise.   Please, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My answer is no, Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Mozart. His voice becomes mechanical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Please. Please. Please.  Please. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Von Swieten and Salieri stand close together. Several sch and students are examining scrolls and manuscripts at the other end of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping his voice  down) This is embarrassing, you know. You  introduced Mozart to some of my  friends and he's begging from  practically all of them. It has to  stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you think of anyone who might  commission some work from him? I've  done my best. I got him to arrange  some Bach for my Sunday concerts. He  got a fee - what I could afford.  Can't you think of anyone who might  do something for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Baron, no. I'm afraid Mozart is  a lost cause. He has managed to  alienate practically the whole of  Vienna. He is constantly drunk. He  never pays his debts. I can't think  of one person to whom I dare recommend  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How sad. It's tragic, isn't it?   Such a talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. Just a moment - as a matter  of fact I think I do know someone  who could commission a work from  him. A very appropriate person to do  so. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opening measures of the Piano Concerto in D Minor ste in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is exactly the same shop which Mozart and Constanze  visited with Leopold. Now Salieri's servant stands in it, waiting. We see a few other customers being served by the staff: renting masks, costumes, etc. One of the staff eme from the back of the shop carrying a large box, which he  hands to Salieri's servant. The servant leaves the shop. Through the window we see him hurrying away through the s street full of passers-by, carriages, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The D Minor Concerto continues. Salieri, alone, eagerly o the box from the costume shop and takes out the same dark cloak and hat that Leopold wore to the masquerade, only n attached to the hat is a dark mask whose mouth is cut int frown, not a laugh. It presents a bitter and menacing  expression. He puts on the cloak, the hat and the mask an turns his back. Suddenly we see the assembled and alarmin image reflected in a full-length mirror. The music swells darkly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tutti of the D Minor Concerto continues, we see  Salieri, dressed in this menacing costume, dark against t snow, stalking through a street which is otherwise lively with people going to various festivities. Some of them we frivolous carnival clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart sits writing at a table. He appears now to be real quite sick. His face expresses pain from his stomach cram There is a gentle knock at the door. He rises, goes to he door and opens it. Immediately there is a SHOCK CUT: The dark, frowning mask stares at him and at us. The viol D Minor chord which opens Don Giovanni is heard. Salieri costume stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Mozart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second chord sounds and fades. Mozart stares in panic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come to commission work from  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mass for the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What dead? Who is dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who deserved a Requiem Mass  and never got one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am only a messenger. Do you accept?   You will be paid well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri extends his hand. In it is a bag of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty ducats. Another fifty when I  have the Mass. Do you accept?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost against his will, Mozart takes the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will you give me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work fast. And be sure to tell no  one what you do. You will see me  again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away. Mozart closes the front door. Instantly we hear the opening of the Requiem Mass (also in D Minor).   Mozart turns and looks up at the portrait of his father o the wall. The portrait stares back. Constanze opens the d from the bedroom. She sees him staring up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi? Wolfi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her with startled eyes. The music breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a strange little giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees the bag of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? Oh! (pouncing on it) Who gave you this? How much is it?  Wolfi, who gave you this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not telling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd think I was mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at her. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Salieri is now wildly animated, totally driven by his confession to Vogler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My plan was so simple, it terrified  me. First I must get the Death Mass  and then achieve the death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogler stares at him in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His funeral - imagine it! The  Cathedral, all Vienna sitting there.  His coffin, Mozart's little coffin  in the middle. And suddenly in that  silence, music. A divine music bursts  out over them all, a great Mass of  Death: Requiem Mass for Wolfgang  Mozart, composed by his devoted friend  Antonio Salieri. What sublimity!  What depth! What passion in the music!  Salieri has been touched by God at  last. And God, forced to listen.   Powerless - powerless to stop it. I  at the end, for once, laughing at  Him. Do you understand? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing that worried me was  the actual killing. How does one do  that? How does one kill a man? It's  one thing to dream about it. It's  very different when you have to do  it, with your own hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his own hands and stares at them. The raging Di Irae from Mozart's Requiem Mass bursts upon us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart sits working frantically at this demonic music. Hi whole expression is one of wildness and engulfing fever. pours wine down his throat, spilling it, and grimaces as hits his stomach. All around him are manuscripts. There is a banging at the front door. Mozart does not hea it; the music raves on. Another knocking comes, louder.  Constanze appears from the bedroom and stares at her  distracted husband. The knocking is repeated again, even  more violently and insistently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi. Wolfi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. The music breaks off. Silence. An enormo bang at the door startles him. Constanze moves to open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't answer it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart springs up. He is clearly terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm not here. Tell him I'm  working on it. Come back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out of he room, into his workroom, and shuts he d Now a little scared herself, Constanze goes to he front d and opens it cautiously. Schikaneder stands there, florid dressed as usual. Lorl is seen peeking out from the kitch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I interrupting something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering into he room) Where's our friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in. But he's working on it.  He said to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. I need it immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes her into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he happy with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees he manuscript on the table, and goes to it eagerl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a page without waiting for a reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the devil is this? Requiem Mass?  Does he think I'm in the funeral  business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart opens he workroom door. We see him as Schikaneder  sees him: wild-eyed, extremely pale and strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave that alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it down, I said! It's nothing  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! I'm sorry! I'm sorry! What have  you got for me? Is it finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The vaudeville, what'd you  think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there's nothing to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles triumphantly. Schikaneder stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I asked you if we could start  rehearsal next week and you said  yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let me see it. Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart, with a bright, rather demented smile presents his head to Schikaneder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. It's all right here, in my  noodle. The rest is just scribbling.  Scribbling and bibbling. Bibbling  and scribbling. Would you like a  drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He giggles. Schikaneder suddenly grabs his lapels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you little clown, do you know  how many people I've hired for you?   Do you know how many people are  waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm paying these people. Do you  realize that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's doing his best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm paying people just to wait for  you. It's ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's ridiculous? Your  libretto, that's what's ridiculous.   Only an idiot would ask Wolfi to  work on that stuff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes? And what's so intelligent  about writing a Requiem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money! Money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mad! She's mad, Wolfi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, and who are you? He's worked  for Kings. For the Emperor. (shouting) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schikaneder suddenly takes Mozart by the arms, and speaks him with intense appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Wolfi. Write it. Please.  Just write it down. On paper. It's  no good to anyone in your head. And  fuck the Death Mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frightened and tearful Lorl sits before Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now calm yourself. Calm. What's the  matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving. I'm not working there  anymore. I'm scared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What has happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what it's like. Herr  Mozart frightens me. He drinks all  day, then takes all that medicine  and it makes him worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What medicine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He has pains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, in his stomach. They bend him  right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm frightened, sir. Really! When he  speaks, he doesn't make any sense.   You know he said he saw - he said he  saw his father. And his father's  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so. He sits there all he  time, doing some silly opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Opera? Opera!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't ask me to go back again.   I'm frightened! I'm very, very  frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistently) Are you sure it's an opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Overture to The Magic Flute begins grandly. To the mu of the slow introduction, we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room, lit by a few candles, appears dirty. The camera shows us again Leopold's portrait on the wall, looking do upon a scene of disorder. Papers litter the table; dirty dishes are piled in the  fireplace; on the forte-piano lies Mozart's Masonic apron woven with symbols. To the more lyrical passage of the  introduction, we see Mozart take up a candle and enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch him stand beside Constanze, who lies asleep. Moz now looks very ill; his wife appears worn out. Tenderly h touches her hair. Then he moves to the cot where his son  Karl lies asleep and kneels, pulls up the child's little  blanket and for a moment lays his own head down beside th boy's. Constanze opens her eyes and stares at him. Mozart rises and returns to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Introduction ends and suddenly the brilliant fast fug begins. Instantly Mozart starts to dance to it, all alone gleefully, like a child. He looks up at his father's port and makes a silly, rude gesture at it. He is, briefly, an irresponsible and happy boy again. Then suddenly there is a gentle knocking at the door. The music fades down. Warily, Mozart crosses and opens he doo The familiar dark chords from Don Giovanni cut across the happy music. It ends. Before him stands the masked strang

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have it yet. It's not  finished. I'm sorry, but I need more  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you neglecting my request?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no! I promise you, I'll give you  a wonderful piece - the best I ever  can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and looks. Constanze has come into the living ro Nervously, Mozart indicates her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my wife, Stanzi. I've been  sick, but I'm all right now. Aren't  I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, sir. He's all right. And  he's working on it very hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me two more weeks. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri contemplates them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sooner you finish, the better  your reward. Work!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes down the stairs. Mozart shuts the door; closes his eyes in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi, I think you really are going  mad. You work like a slave for that  idiot actor who won't give you a  penny and here. This is not a ghost!   This is a real man who puts down  real money. Why on earth don't you  finish it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will not look at her or reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me one reason I can understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't write it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's killing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is really awful. You're  drunk, aren't you? Be honest - tell  me - you've been drinking. And I'm  so stupid I stay here and listen to  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly she starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not fair! I worry about you all  the time. I try to help you all I  can and you just drink and talk  nonsense and - and frighten me! It's  not fair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her tears flow. Mozart looks at her helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Let me sit here. Let me stay  here with you. I promise I won't say  all word. I'll just be here, so you  know no one's going to hurt you.  Please, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down tearfully, staring at him. We hear the Rex Tremendai Majestatis from the Requiem and see on the wall the portrait of Leopold Mozart looking do The camera pans slowly downward from it back to the table Mozart is writing the music. He looks up and sees that  Constanze is fast asleep in her chair. Mozart gets up qui He puts on his hat and cloak, takes a bottle of wine and  tiptoes from the house. Without stopping, the music chang from the heavy Requiem to the light-hearted patter of the Papa-Papa duet from The Magic Flute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This little wooden structure stands in a courtyard in the tenement by the Weiden. Inside, we see a table, chairs, a forte-piano, bottles and a chaos of papers. Strewn about the chairs are the three actresses, giggling. Schikaneder and Mozart, both drunk, are singing the duet of the two b people. The actor sings Papageno and the composer, in a  soprano voice, sings Papagena at the keyboard. Absurdly,  they end up rubbing noses and fall on each other's necks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart, drunk and happy, staggers back through the snow. There are a few people about. He goes into his apartment  building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes through he door and stares across the living roo at an open bedroom door. Puzzled, he crosses. The bedroom is also empty. We see Constanze's empty bed;  Karl's empty bed; empty closets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanzi? Stanzi-marini-bini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks about him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frau Weber sits grimly talking. Mozart sits also, complet exhausted and passive under the rain of her constant spee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not coming back, you know.  She's gone for good. I did it and  I'm proud of it. 'Leave,' I said.  'Right away! Take he child and go,  just go. Here's the money! Go to the  Spa and get your health back - that's  if you can.' I was shocked. Shocked  to my foundation. Is that my girl?   Can that be my Stanzi? The happy  little moppet I brought up, that  poor trembling thing? Oh, you monster!   No one exists but you, do they? You  and your music! Do you know how often  she's sat in that very chair, weeping  her eyes out of her head because of  you? I warned her. 'Choose a man,  not a baby,' I said. But would she  listen? Who listens? 'He's just a  silly boy,' she says. Silly, my arse.   Selfish - that's all you are. Selfish!  Selfish, selfish, selfish, selfish,  selfish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with a scream Madame Weber's voice turns into the shr packing coloratura of the second act aria of the Queen of the Night, in The Magic Flute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On stage we see the QUEEN OF THE NIGHT fantastically cost furiously urging her daughter to kill Sarastro. As she si we see the interior of the theatre, now re-arranged from  when we last visited it to watch the Cabaret. An audience ordinary German citizens stands in the pit area, or sits: they are rapt and excited. The theatre also possesses boxes; some of these show clos curtains - their inhabitants presumably engaged in privat intimacies. In one of them sits Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing furiously) A hellish wrath within my heart is  seething! Death and destruction Flame  around my throne! If not by thee  Sarastro's light be extinguished.  Then be thou mine own daughter never  more! Rejected be forever! So sundered  be forever All the bonds of kin and  blood! Hear! Hear! Hear God of  Vengeance! Hear thy Mother's vow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunder and lightning. She disappears amidst tremendous  applause from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the poster for The Magic Flute, the name Emmanuel  Schikaneder should appear very, very large and the name o Mozart quite small: I. & R. priv. Weiden Theatre The Actors of the Imperial and Royal Privileged Theatre of the Weiden Have the honour to perform

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Grand Opera in Two Acts Emmanuel Schikaneder (The Cast List)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music is by Herr Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Herr Mozart out of respect for a gracious and honourable Public, and  from friendship for the author of this piece, will today  direct the orchestra in person. The book of the opera, furnished with two copperplates, o which is engraved Herr Schikaneder in the costume he wear for the role of Papageno, may be had at the box office fo 30 kr. Prices of admission are as usual To begin at 7 o'clock

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT -1790'S
dialogues.text: We CUT TO the scene immediately before Papageno's song, E Madchen oder Weibchen. Papageno, played by Schikaneder,  dressed in his costume of feathers, is trying to get thro a mysterious door. A voice calls from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papageno recoils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merciful Gods! If only I knew by  which door I came in. (to audience) Which was it? Was it this one? Come  on, tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papageno recoils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I can't go forward and I can't  go back. Oh, this is awful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He weeps extravagantly. In the pit, Mozart indicates to the first violinist to ta over as conductor. He slips from his place and goes steal backstage. We follow him. Over the scene we hear Papageno being addressed by the First Priest in stern tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on stage) Man, thou hast deserved to wander  forever in the darkest chasms of the  earth. The gentle Gods have remitted  thy punishment, but yet thou shalt  never feel the Divine Content of the  consecrated ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well, I'm not alone in that. Just  give me a decent glass of wine -  that's divine content enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. An enormous goblet of wine appears out of the e We follow Mozart into the wings. Actors and actresses sta around in fantastic costumes. We see a flying chariot and parts of a huge snake lying about. Also the scenery door a temple with the word 'Wisdom' inscribed on the pediment Mozart walks to where there stands a keyboard glockenspie with several manuals, and a musician waiting to play it.  Silently Mozart indicates that he wishes to play the  instrument himself. On stage Schikaneder is being addressed haughtily by the  First Priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, hast thou no other desire on  earth, but just to eat and drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Schikaneder) Well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually I do have a rather  weird feeling in my heart. Perhaps  it's just indigestion. But you know,  I really would like - I really do  want - something even nicer than  food and drink. Now what on earth  could that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the audience and winks at them. They laugh. Now Papageno's aria (Ein Madchen oder Weibchen) begins. I is interpolated, as he pretends to play his magic bells,  with the glockenspiel actually being played off-stage by  Mozart. Schikaneder looks into the pit and does not see M conducting. He looks into the wings and realizes the situ with amusement. He sings joyfully and the audience watche entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sweetheart or a pretty little wife  is Papageno's wish. A willing,  billing, lovey dovey Would be My  most tasty little dish. Be my most  tasty little dish! Be my most tasty  little dish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then that would be eating and drinking  I'd live like a Prince without  thinking. The wisdom of old would be  mine - A woman's much better than  wine! Then that would be eating and  drinking! The wisdom of old would be  mine - A woman's much better than  wine. She's much better than wine!  She's much better than wine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (encore, lightly, as  before) A sweetheart or a pretty little wife  is Papageno's wish. A willing,  billing, lovey dovey Would be My  most tasty little dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to net one birdie only And I  will stop feeling so lonely. But if  she won't fly to my aid, Then into a  ghost I must fade. I need to net one  birdie only But if she won't fly to  my aid, Then into a ghost I must  fade.  To a ghost I must fade! To a  ghost I must fade!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (encore) A sweetheart or a pretty little wife  is Papageno's wish. A willing,  billing, lovey dovey Would be My  most tasty little dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At present the girls only peck me.  Their cruelty surely will wreck me.  But one little beak in my own, And  I'll up to heaven be flown! At present  the girls only peck me. But one little  beak in my own, And I'll up to heaven  be flown. Up to heaven be flown! Up  to heaven be flown!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At certain moments we see the stage from Salieri's point view: Schikaneder singing, then pretending to play; and t we see Mozart playing the glockenspiel with great flouris in the wings. Then, suddenly, the actor mimes playing, an no sound comes. He mimes again, but still nothing comes. looks offstage in anxiety; there is evidently some commot People are looking down on the floor. The song comes to a near-halt. Schikaneder stares. Then the comedian signals the deputy conductor to pick up the song and finish it. A this moment Salieri gets up and hastily leaves his box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the actress playing Papagena, wearing an old tatte cloak and about to tie a little painted cloth representin hideous old woman over her face. She is looking worriedly down at Mozart, who is lying unconscious on the floor. A few people around him are trying to revive him. One has put a wet handkerchief around his temples. Another is hol a small bottle of smelling salts. There are voices saying 'Doctor! Take him to a dressing room. Someone call a carr Take him home.' Etc. Papagena is urged to go on stage by distracted stage manager. Suddenly we hear the voice of  Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a carriage. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The actors step back respectfully. He stoops and picks up the frail composer in his arms. Mozart is quite limp and  Salieri has to fling his arms around his own neck. All th is watched nervously by Schikaneder on stage whilst perfo his scene with Papagena as an ugly old woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am, my angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) What? Who the devil are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've taken pity on you, my angel. I  heard your wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, thank you! How wonderful.   Some people get all the luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audience laughter. The actress raises the little painted  cloth with the ugly old face on it to show her own pretty young one to the audience. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you've got to promise me  faithfully you'll remain true to me  forever. Then you'll see how tenderly  your little birdie will love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) I can't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, promise then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean - now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course now. Right away, before I  get any older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know! I mean you're a  delicious, delightful, delectable  little bird, but don't you think you  might be just a little tough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amorously) Oh, I'm tender enough for you, my  boy. I'm tender enough for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waiting sedan chair. Mozart has recovered consciousness but looks exceedingly ill. Salieri has set him down in th winter's night. Snow is falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? Is it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking you home. You're not well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I have to get back. I have -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to collapse again. Salieri helps him into the s The door is shut. The chair sets off and Salieri strides  beside it, through the mean street. A lantern with a cand swings from the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Salieri enters carrying the lantern from sedan chair. He is followed by Mozart, carried in the arm of one of the porters. The room is now really in complete disarray. The table is piled high with music: the pages o the Requiem lie amongst many empty wine bottles. The port carries Mozart into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This room is miserably neglected. The bed is unmade, clot lie about on the floor. A sock has been stuck into the br pane of one window. The porter lays Mozart down on the bed as Salieri lights  candles from the lantern to reveal plates of half-eaten f and other signs left by a man whose wife has departed. It obviously very cold. Another very small bed nearby belong to the child, Karl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing the porter  the lantern) Thank you. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The porter leaves the room. Mozart stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely singing) Papa! Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens his eyes and sees Salieri staring down at him. H smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps him to sit up and takes off his coat and his sho and puts a coverlet around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here! She's not well, either.  She went to the Spa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean she's not coming back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so good to me. Truly. Thank  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean to come to my opera. You are  the only colleague who did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struggles to loosen his cravat. Salieri does it for hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never miss anything that you  had written. You must know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is only a vaudeville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. It is a sublime piece. The  grandest operone. I tell you, you  are the greatest composer known to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have bad fancies. I don't sleep  well anymore. Then I drink too much,  and think stupid things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor thinks I am. But -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too young to be so sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a violent knocking at the front door. Mozart sta and looks around wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I answer it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No, it's him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man. He's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knocking increases in loudness, terrifying Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to go away. Tell him I'm  still working on it. Don't let him  in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Ask him if he'd give me some  money now. Tell him if he would,  that would help me finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows. He knows!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri goes to the front door and opens it to reveal  Schikaneder, who has obviously come straight from the the He still wears his bird make-up and under his street cloa his feathered costume is clearly seen.
