He has with him th three actresses, also looking anxious and also in make-up the three attendants in The Magic Flute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Salieri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am looking after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's sleeping now. Better not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. He's just exhausted. He  became dizzy, that's all. We should  let him rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell him we were here, won't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And say everything went wonderfully.   A triumph-de-luxe - say that! Tell  him the audience shouted his name a  hundred times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (to the actresses) And congratulations to all of you.  It was superb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you! Thank you, Excellency!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schikaneder produces a bag of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, give him this. This  is his share. That should cheer him  up, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed. Goodnight to you all  now. It was perfection - truly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) Goodnight, Your Excellency.   Goodnight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They bob and curtsey. Schikaneder stares at Salieri, unea vaguely suspicious. Salieri smiles back at him and shuts door. He stays for a moment, thinking. He contemplates th money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is sitting up in bed, staring at the door. It open Salieri returns. He holds in his hand the bag of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri pours the coins out of the bag onto the coverlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to give you this. And if you  finish the work by tomorrow night,  he will pay you another hundred  ducats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart looks at the coins astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another? But that's too soon! Tomorrow  night? It's impossible! Did he say a  hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Can I - could I help you, in  any way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you? Actually, you could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear friend, it would be my  greatest pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'd have to swear not to tell  a soul. I'm not allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's all here in my head.   It's just ready to be set down. But  when I'm dizzy like this my eyes  won't focus. I can't write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, let us try together. I'd regard  it as such an honour. Tell me, what  is this work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mass. A Mass for the Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trivial dance music is playing. Constanze is doing a walt with a young OFFICER in military uniform. At the moment w see her, she stops abruptly, as if in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go back to Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel wrong. I feel wrong being  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laying a hand on her  arm) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is sitting up in bed, propped against pillows. The coins lie on the coverlet; many candles burn in the necks bottles. Salieri, without coat or wig, is seated at an  improvised worktable. On it are blank sheets of music pap quills, and ink. Also the score of the Requiem Mass as so far composed. Mozart is bright-eyed with a kind of fever. Salieri is also possessed with an obviously feverish desi to put down the notes as quickly as Mozart can dictate th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did I stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting the  manuscript) The end of the Recordare - Statuens  in parte dextra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now the Confutatis. Confutatis  Maledictis. When the wicked are  confounded. Flammis acribus addictis.   How would you translate that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consigned to flames of woe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire which never dies. Burning one  forever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come. Let's begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes his pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confutatis Maledictis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ended in F Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now - A minor. Suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri writes the key signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Common time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri writes this, and continues now to write as swiftl and urgently as he can, at Mozart's dictation. He is obvi highly expert at doing this and hardly hesitates. His spe however, can never be too fast for Mozart's impatient min

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start with the voices. Basses first.  Second beat of the first measure -  A. (singing the note) Con-fu-ta-tis. (speaking) Second measure, second beat. (singing) Ma-le-dic-tis. (speaking) G-sharp, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third measure, second beat starting  on E. (singing) Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis. (speaking) And fourth measure, fourth beat - D. (singing) Ma-le-dic-tis, flam-mis a-cri-bus ad- dic-tis. (speaking) Do you have that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri sings back the first six measures of the bass lin After the first two measures a chorus of basses fades in the soundtrack and engulfs his voice. They stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now the tenors. Fourth beat of  the first measure - C. (singing) Con-fu-ta-tis. (speaking) Second measure, fourth beat on D. (singing) Ma-le-dic-tis. (speaking) All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourth measure, second beat - F. (singing) Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis, flam- mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice is lost on the last words, as tenors engulf it take over the soundtrack, singing their whole line from t beginning, right to the end of the sixth measure where th basses stopped, but he goes on mouthing the sounds with t Salieri writes feverishly. We see his pen jotting down th notes as quickly as possible: the ink flicks onto the pag The music stops again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the orchestra. Second bassoon  and bass trombone with the basses.  Identical notes and rhythm. (He hurriedly hums  the opening notes of  the bass vocal line) The first bassoon and tenor trombone -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (labouring to keep up) Please! Just one moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart glares at him, irritated. His hands move impatient Salieri scribbles frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It couldn't be simpler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing) First bassoon and tenor trombone -  what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the tenors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also identical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. The instruments to go with  the voices. Trumpets and timpani,  tonic and dominant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He again hums the bass vocal line from the beginning,  conducting. On the soundtrack, we hear the second bassoon and bass trombone play it with him and the first bassoon tenor trombone come in on top, playing the tenor vocal li We also hear the trumpets and timpani. The sound is bare grim. It stops at the end of the sixth measure. Salieri s writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. Now for the Fire. (he smiles) Strings in unison - ostinato on all -  like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sings the urgent first measure of the ostinato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) Second measure on B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sings the second measure of the ostinato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) Do you have me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri sings the first two measures of the string ostina

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Good, good - yes! Put it down. And  the next measures exactly the same,  rising and rising - C to D to E, up  to the dominant chord. Do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Salieri writes, Mozart sings the ostinato from the  beginning, but the unaccompanied strings overwhelm his vo on the soundtrack, playing the first six bars of their  agitated accompaniment. They stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes - go on. The Voca Me.  Suddenly sotto voce. Write that down:  sotto voce, pianissimo. Voca me cum  benedictis. Call me among the blessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is now sitting bolt upright, hushed and inspired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C Major. Sopranos and altos in thirds.   Altos on C. Sopranos above. (singing the alto  part) Vo-ca, vo-ca me, vo-ca me cum be-ne- dic-tis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sopranos up to F on the second 'Voca'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and on 'dictis'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He writes feverishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And underneath, just violins -  arpeggio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sings the violin figure under the Voca Me (Bars 7,8,9)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) The descending scale in eighth notes,  and then back suddenly to the fire  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sings the ostinato phrase twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking) And that's it. Do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently) Do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let me hear it. All of it. The  whole thing from the beginning -  now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire Confutatis bursts over the room, as Mozart sna the manuscript pages from Salieri and reads from it, sing Salieri sits looking on in wondering astonishment. The mu continues right through the following scenes, to the end the movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carriage is driving fast through the night. Snow lies o the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE CARRIAGE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The carriage is filled with passengers. Among them Consta and Karl, her young son. They are sleepless and sway to t motion of the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart lying in bed exhausted, but still dictating urgent We do not hear what he is saying to Salieri, who still si writing assiduously. Mozart is looking very sick: sweat i pouring from his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage, moving through the night, to the sound of t music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart still dictating; Salieri still writing without sto EXT. VIENNA STREET - DAWN - 1790'S. The carriage has arrived. Constanze and her son alight wi other passengers. Postillions attend to the horses. She t her boy's hand. It is a cold wintry dawn. The music stutters to a close. End of the Confutatis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to rest a bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. I'm not tired at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll stop for just a moment. Then  we'll do the Lacrimosa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can keep going, I assure you.   Shall we try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you stay with me while I sleep  a little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was foolish. I thought you did not  care for my work - or me. Forgive  me. Forgive me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart closes his eyes. Salieri stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze and Karl approach along the cobbled street, han in hand toward their house. Snow lies in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart lies asleep in the bed, holding the last pages of manuscript. Salieri lies across from him on Karl's small in his shirt sleeves and waistcoat. The child's bed is  obviously too small for him and he is forced in to a cram position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constanze and Karl arrive at the door. They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is as disordered as before, save that the table, previ littered with pages, is now completely bare. Constanze lo at it with surprise and enters the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mozart is asleep in the bed. Salieri is dozing on the nea child's bed. The room is full of the trailing smoke from  guttering and guttered candles. Startled by Constanze's  entrance and her young son, Salieri scrambles up. As he d so, he attempts to button his waistcoat, but does it inep so that the vestment becomes bunched up, making him look  absurd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband is ill, ma'am. He took  sick. I brought him home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you very much. You can  go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs me, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he doesn't. And I don't want you  here. Just go, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked me to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm asking you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices a movement from the bed. Mozart wakes. He see Constanze and smiles with real joy. Forgetting Salieri, s goes to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi, I'm back. I'm still very angry  with you, but I missed you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws herself on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never leave you again. If you'll  just try a little harder to be nice  to me. And I'll try to do better,  too. We must. We must! This was just  silly and stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs her husband desperately. He stares at her with  obvious relief, not able to speak. Suddenly she sees the  manuscript in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at it and recognizes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, not this. Not this, Wolfi!   You're not to work on this ever again!   I've decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes it from his weak hand. At the same moment Salie reaches out his hand to take it and add it to the pile on the table. She stares at him, trying to understand - suspicious and  frightened and at the same time unable to make a sound. M makes a convulsive gesture to reclaim the pages. The coin brought by Salieri fall on the floor.  Karl runs after th laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Salieri) This is not his handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was assisting him. He asked  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not going to work on this  anymore. It is making him ill. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She extends her hand for the Requiem, as she stands up.   Salieri hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard) Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With extreme reluctance - it costs him agony to do it -  Salieri hands over the score of the Requiem to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She marches with the manuscript over to a large chest in room, opens it, throws the manuscript inside, shuts the l locks it and pockets the key. Involuntarily Salieri stret out his arms for the lost manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But - but - but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at her, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I regret we have no servants to show  you out, Herr Salieri. Respect my  wish and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, I will respect his. He asked  me to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other in mutual hatred. She turns to th bed. Mozart appears to have gone to sleep again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfi? (louder) Wolfi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to the bed. The child is playing with the coins the floor. Faintly we hear the start of the Lacrimosa fro the Requiem. Salieri watches as she touches her husband's hand. As the music grows, we realize that Mozart is dead. CU, Constanze staring wide-eyed in dawning apprehension. CU, Salieri also comprehending hat he has been cheated. The music rises. CU, The child on the floor, playing with the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lacrimosa continues through all of the following: a s group of people emerges from the side door into the raw, day, accompanying a cheap wooden coffin. The coffin is bo by a gravedigger and Schikaneder in mourning clothes. The load it onto a cart, drawn by a poor black horse. All the rest are in black, also: Salieri, Von Swieten, Constanze her son, Karl, Madame Weber and her youngest daughter Sop and even Lorl, the maid. It is drizzling. The cart sets o The group follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group has already passed beyond the city limits follo the miserable cart. The Lacrimosa accompanies them with i measured thread. The drizzle of rain has now become heavy. One by one, the group breaks up and shelters under the trees. The cart mo on toward the cemetery, alone, followed by nobody, growin more and more distant. They watch it go. Salieri and Von Swieten shake hands mournfully, the water soaking their black tall hats. Schikaneder is in tears.  Constanze is near collapse. Salieri moves to assist her, she turns away from him, seeking the arm of Cavalieri. Ma Weber takes Karl's hand. The music builds to its climax on Dona Eis Pacem! We CUT  back to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning light fills the room. Old Salieri sits weeping  convulsively, as the music stops. Tears stream down his f Vogler watches him, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why? Why? Why add to your misery  by confessing to murder? You didn't  kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you didn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I poisoned his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does that make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son, why should you want all Vienna  to believe you a murderer? Is that  your penance? Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Father. From now on no one will  be able to speak of Mozart without  thinking of me. Whenever they say  Mozart with love, they'll have to  say Salieri with loathing. And that's  my immortality - at last! Our names  will  be tied together for eternity -  his in fame and mine in infamy. At  least it's better than the total  oblivion he'd planned for me, your  merciful God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my son, my poor son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You  serve a wicked God. He killed Mozart,  not I. Took him, snatched him away,  without pity. He destroyed His beloved  rather than let a mediocrity like me  get the smallest share in his glory.   He doesn't care. Understand that.  God cares nothing for the man He  denies and nothing either for the  man He uses. He broke Mozart in half  when He'd finished with him, and  threw him away. Like an old, worn  out flute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has eased off. A LOCAL PRIEST with two boy acoly is standing beside an open communal grave. Mozart's body lifted out of the cheap pine box in a sack. We see that the grave contains twenty other such sacks. T gravedigger throws the one containing Mozart amongst the  others. An assistant pours quicklime over the whole pile them. The acolytes swing their censers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord giveth. The Lord taketh  away. Blessed be the name of the  Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did He do it? Why didn't He kill  me? I had no value. What was the  use, keeping me alive for thirty-two  years of torture? Thirty-two years  of honours and awards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears off the Civilian Medal and Chain with which the  Emperor invested him and has been wearing the whole time throws it across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being bowed to and saluted, called  'distinguished - distinguished  Salieri' - by men incapable of  distinguishing! Thirty-two years of  meaningless fame to end up alone in  my room, watching myself become  extinct. My music growing fainter,  all the time fainter, until no one  plays it at all. And his growing  louder, filling the world with wonder.  And everyone who loves my sacred art  crying, Mozart! Bless you, Mozart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. An attendant comes in, cheerful and heart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Professor! Time for  the water closet. And then we've got  your favourite breakfast for you -  sugar-rolls. (to Vogler) He loves those. Fresh sugar-rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salieri ignores him and stares only at the priest, who st back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Father. I'll speak for you.   I speak for all mediocrities in the  world. I am their champion. I am  their patron saint. On their behalf  I deny Him, your God of no mercy.   Your God who tortures men with  longings they can never fulfill. He  may forgive me: I shall never forgive  Him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signs to the attendant, who wheels him in his chair ou of the room. The priest stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor is filled with patients in white linen smock all taking their morning exercise walk in the care of nur and nuns. They form a long, wretched, strange procession some of them are clearly very disturbed. As Old Salieri i pushed through them in his wheelchair, he lifts his hands them in benediction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mediocrities everywhere, now and to  come: I absolve you all! Amen! Amen!   Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, he turns full-face to the camera and blesses us audience, making the Sign of the Cross. Underneath we hea stealing in and growing louder, the tremendous Masonic Fu Music of Mozart. On the last four chords, we
